Mr. Speaker(Hon.G. H. Mackay) took the chair at 2.30 p.m., and read prayers.
WORLD WHEAT CONFERENCE.

Mr. HILL.- I ask the Acting Leader of the House what instructions, if any, were given toMr. MacDougall, who is representing Australia at the World Wheat Conference at Geneva? Has Mr. MacDougall power to bind Australian wheatgrowers to any determination arrived at by the conference, or will the wheatgrowers of the Commonwealth be consulted before any arrangement is made withother countries? What attitude will Mr. MacDougall adopt in regard to the proposed limitation of production ?

Mr. LATHAM.- I cannot state in detail the instructions given to Mr. MacDougall, but the fact was impressed upon him that Australia's position as a wheat producer is very different from that of the United States of America, for instance. The Government does not consider that any restriction of production would be in the interests of Australia, But if such restriction were decided upon, a distinction should be made between countries which have large unmarketed surpluses and other wheat-producing countries. Mr. MacDougall has no power to bind the Commonwealth to any decision. No report has yetbeen received by the Government regarding the work of the conference. If such a report should contain definite proposals, the Government will have to determine in what direction the real advantage of the Commonwealth lies, and, of course, the closest attention will be given to the interests of the wheat-growers, whose views were expressed at therecent conference in Melbourne.
ROYAL VISIT TO AUSTRALIA.

Mr. HUTCHIN.-The Sydney Morning Herald of to-day reports that arrangements have been made by the Governments of the Commonwealth and the States for the visit to Australia of a member of the British Royal family. Can the
Acting Leader of the House state whether that report is authoritative, and whether the Australian public may confidently anticipate such a welcome event ?
Mr. LATHAM.- At the present stage, I am unable to make any announcement on the subject.
SECRETARY TO THE TREASURY.
Visit to London.

Mr. BEASLEY.-In view of the special qualifications alleged to be possessed by the right honorable member for Flinders (Mr. Bruce) whenthe bill for the appointment of a Resident Minister in London was before the House, can the Acting Leader of the House explain the reason why Mr. H. J. Sheehan, Secretary to the Treasury, has been sent to London at great cost to the Commonwealth? Is Mr. Sheehan to do the work which the Resident Minister might have done? Does this arrangement indicate that the Resident Minister has failed to discharge the duties for which he was appointed?

Mr. LATHAM.- Mr. J. R. Collins recently relinquished the position of financial adviser to the representative of Australia in London, a positionwhich he had held for some years. The work of the Treasury is becoming increasingly complex, and demands a much more extensive knowledge, and, indeed, higher qualifications, than in earlier years. Mr. Sheehan has been sent to London to enable him to increase his already great ability to serve the people of the Commonwealth.
EXPORT OF AUSTRALIAN APPLES.

Mr. BLACKLOW.- Has the Minister for Commerce read in the Sydney Morning Herald a statement by Mr. McCann regarding the possibility of increasing the market in Scandinavia for Australian apples? Mr. McCann stated also that the Commonwealth lags behind Canada and the United States of America in its methods for obtaining publicity. Will the Minister have an investigation made with a view to the development of the Scandinavian market?
Mr. STEWART.- I shall read the statement, and have the matter to which it refers investigated.
MARKETING CONTROL BOARDS.

Mr. FORDE.- According to reports published in this morning's newspapers, the State Ministers for Agriculture have decided to urge the Commonwealth Government to introduce legislation to facilitate the establishment of Marketing Control Boards, whilst the Chamber of Commerce inSydney is protesting to the Commonwealth against any further government interference with industry. I ask the Acting Leader of the House if these communications have been received by the Commonwealth Government, and, if so, have they been considered ?

Mr. LATHAM.- The Minister for Agriculture in New South Wales has conveyed to the Minister for Commerce a resolution of the recent conference of State Ministers for Agriculture, but, so far as I am aware, no communication on the subject has been received from the Sydney Chamber of Commerce. The recommendation of the Ministers for Agriculture was brought before Cabinet in accordance with an undertaking by the Minister for Commerce, and Mr. Main will be informed that an opportunity for the discussion of this matter will be afforded at the forthcoming conference of Commonwealth and State Ministers.
TRAVELLERS FROM OVERSEAS.
Customs Examination.

Mr. WHITE.- On the 10th May, the honorable member for Franklin (Mr. Blacklow) asked a question, without notice, regarding a report published in the Sunday Sun of the 7th May, relating to complaints made by a new arrival in the Commonwealth, Mr. Sheridan, to the effect that he had been discourteously treated by customs officers at Fremantle in connexion with the examination of his passport. The honorable member for Swan (Mr. Gregory) also wrote to me on the subject.

A full report has been obtained from the Collector of Customs at Fremantle, and, in my opinion, it discloses that the newspaper account was an exaggeration of what actually occurred. The customs officers are responsible for carrying out the provisions of the Immigration

Restriction Act, which prohibits the entry into Australia of any person who is likely to become a charge upon the public by reason of infirmity of mind or body or insufficiency of means of support. Obviously, officers could not carry out their duties under the act without personally questioning new arrivals. The substance of Mr. Sheridan's complaint appears to be that he was subjected to an inquisition, which lasted twenty minutes, regarding his private and financial affairs, and that questions were put to him which had no bearing on his entry into Australia. He further complained that his wife was subjected to what he termed an " equally close and impertinent examination."

Twenty persons were noted by the Principal Medical Officer for theport as requiring further examination by the customs for thepurpose of the Immigration Restriction Act. Mr. Sheridan came under notice because of his age and defective vision. The ship was not boarded by the customs officer till 7 a.m., and the necessary inquiries were completed shortly after 8 a.m., so that the average time taken in examining each of the twenty persons interviewed was only a few minutes. The questions put to Mr. Sheridan were of a routine character, and were such as are necessary to satisfy the requirements of the Australian immigration laws. There does not appear to be any goodreason to believe that the officer showed any discourtesy in his examination. This is borne out by the senior officer, who was also in attendance.

I am of the opinion that Mr. Sheridan's statements, as reported in the press, are exaggerated, and were no doubt duo to his resentment at having to answer any question at all regarding his financial position. Mrs.Sheridan was not questioned, except to ascertain the address of her son, whois at present in Australia,but whose address Mr. Sheridan could not supply. Customs officers are well aware that passengers are entitled to every courtesy and assistance, and they endeavour to carry out their duties in a tactful manner, making due allowance for those passengers who feel aggrieved at being asked personal questions to satisfy the requirements of the Im migration Act. .
COMMONWEALTH CLOTHING FACTORY.

Mr. HOLLOWAY. - Is the Commonwealth Government associated with the Victorian Government and the Chamber of Manufactures in the effort to prevent the Commonwealth Government Clothing Factory from continuing to tender for contracts for uniforms other than purely naval and military uniforms?

Mr. LATHAM.- My only personal information on the matter has been derived from the press, where I have read the statement that it is proposed to institute proceedings against the Commonwealth for the purpose of obtaining a declaration as to the rights or powers of the Commonwealth to utilize the clothing factory in the manner mentioned. In such proceedings the Commonwealth would be against those who are proposing to initiate the action. During past years many representations have been made to various Commonwealth administrations on this subject. This is a permanent problem; but I am not aware that any particularly recent communications have been received from either of the sources mentioned.
WIRELESS BROADCASTING.
S tar ting-pricebetting-commission's Head-quarters.

Mr. JENNINGS.-In view of the protests and police reports that starting-price betting is encouraged by the broadcasting of starters and prices during race meetings, is it the intention of the Commonwealth Government to bring b class broadcasting stations into line with the policy adopted by the national stations, and to prohibit the inclusion of starting information in broadcast programmes?

Mr. ARCHDALEPARKHILL. - It is primarily the business of State administrations, if they think fit, to deal with starting-price betting as a normal question or social evil. If the States are determined to take action in the matter, it should, in my opinion, be done, not in a piecemeal fashion by dealing with one offending agency only, but in a complete manner, by dealing with all such agencies. I have already said on numerous occasions that any proposals which the States may place before the Postal Department will be sympathetically considered. The b class stations are under the control of the Postal Department, and that portion of the honorable member's question relating to them will receive consideration.

Mr. JOHNLAWSON.- Has the Postmaster-General noticed in the press a report which suggests that the headquarters of the Australian Broadcasting Commission may shortly be removed from Sydney to Melbourne; and, if so, is he in a position to deny or affirm that statement ?
Mr. ARCHDALEPARKHILL.- So far as I am aware, there is no intention to alter the present arrangements.
COMMONWEALTH PUBLIC SERVICE.
Basic Wage.
Sir HENRYGULLETT. - Has the

Government yet reached a decision as to whether the new basis of calculating the cost of living adopted by the Arbitration Court is to be applied to the remuneration of the Commonwealth Public Service?
Mr. LATHAM.- No decision has yet been reached on that matter.
INVALID AND OLD-AGE PENSIONS.

Mr. JAMES.- Is the Attorney-General aware that new claims for old-age pensions are paid on the basis of 15s. a week where the applicant was in receipt of food relief, irrespective of the fact that the food relief ceased immediately the pension was paid, and that the department will not make up the amount to the maximum pension unless it receives a notification from the food relief officer that the applicant is not in receipt of food relief? In view of the fact that the pensioner is being deprived of 2s. 6d. a week during the period of suspension, will the right honorable gentleman see that the payment is made retrospective from the date on which the food relief ceases?
Mr. LATHAM.-I shall see that inquiries are made into the subject raised by the honorable member, with the object of taking any action that may appear to be necessary and fair.

Mr. ROSEVEAR.-Is the Attorney-General aware that the pensions department, in cases in which invalid pensioners have their pensions stopped. because in the opinion of the department's doctor they are not entitled to them, and in which subsequently the pensions are restored because of the weight of medical evidence, is not making good the payments which were stopped during the period of suspension? Does the Government approve of such an attitude on the part of the pensions department?

Mr. LATHAM.-I do not pretend to have an accurate knowledge of the subject to which the honorable member has referred; but it will be seen that, if it were laid down as a rule that whenever an invalid pension has been suspended on account of medical opinion or evidence, and the pension at a later date is restored, the pension should be paid for the intervening period, some quite unreasonable positions would arise. I shall, however, see whether it is possible to introduce any administrative change which will provide for cases in which there has been an immediate review, to which I understand the honorable member's question refers.
Mr. Rosevear.-The review should be within about a month.
Mr. LATHAM.- Practically an immediate review.
Mr. BEASLEY.- Is it a recent policy of the Government to appoint men to stand behind the counters at the post offices in order to spy on pensioners as they enter?
Mr. ArchdaleParkhill. - That is not the policy of the Government.

Mr. BEASLEY.- Is it the policy of the Government to appoint men to stand behind the counter when the pensioners are being paid, to take the numbers of the pension cards, and then to follow the pensioners to their homes, and adopt all kinds of other methods in order to intercept them and discover means of cancelling their pensions ?

Mr. LATHAM.- I doubt whether any honorable member would object to information being obtained concerning the pensions that are paid from the public moneys of the Commonwealth; but I have no knowledge whatever of objectionable practices of the description suggested. The only objectionable practices that the Government has under consideration at the moment are associated with organizations whose representatives post themselves outside offices where pensions are being paid, and pester the pensioners for subscriptions to their leagues.
Mr. James.- Where is that done?

Mr. LATHAM.-In Victoria, at least. The Government is considering whether action ought not to be taken to prevent pensioners being, in effect, compelled to contribute an amount, small though it may be, towards the support of these organizations, which profess to be acting in their interests.

Mr. McGRATH.- I wish to direct the attention of the Government to the disgraceful and despicable tactics that are employed by certain individuals towards old-age pensioners. In Ballarat, these persons intercept old people and invalids as they leave the pensions office, and demand 3d. from each, the proceeds being devoted to keeping these loafers in an easy job. Will the Attorney-General take steps to see that these tactics are prevented in future?

Mr. LATHAM.- I have given some attention to this matter, and it appears to me that it may be perfectly well dealt with by the State police preventing the obstruction of the highway. I intend to communicate with the Victorian authorities with a view to bringing about the cessation of the practice.

Mr. A.GREEN.- Will the Attorney-General cause inquiries to be made concerning persons who lay information against old-age pensioners in regard to the amount of money or the meals that they may receive from outside sources, with a view to providing that such information must be laid in the form of an affidavit instead of being furnished by anonymous letter? In country districts, particularly, any man may have enemies, and although much of the information furnished anonymously is palpably dictated by malice, it nevertheless causes acute mental anguish to the pensioners.

Mr. LATHAM.- Apparently, the honorable gentleman suggests that some inquiry should be made as to whether the department should pay attention to communications of the character to which he has referred. It would be difficult indeed to lay down a general rule; each case needs to be considered and dealt with on its merits. Honorable members, but particularly Ministers, are accustomed to receiving anonymous letters, and these are seldom highly complimentary in character. Occasionally, something of value is discovered in them, but probably the majority of them find their way into the waste-paper basket.

Mr. JAMES.-Can the Acting Leader of the House inform honorable members if the Government of any country in the world has sunk to the mean and despicable depths which this Government reached when it introduced and passed amendments to the Invalid and Old-age Pensions Act confiscating the property of the aged and infirm?
Mr. SPEAKER.- Order ! The honorable gentleman may not reflect on any act done by this Parliament. It is optional with the Acting Leader of the House whether he will reply to the question.
Mr. LATHAM.- I reply to the question by saying that the Australian invalid and old-age pensions system, in its present form, is the most generous in the whole world.
PETROL ROYAL COMMISSION.

Mr. GREGORY.-Is the Attorney-General satisfied that under the legislation recently passed by this House the petrol royal commission will have full power to obtain the information desired in regard to intra-state trading? If not, will it be necessary for legislation to be passed by one or more of the States, or for the Federal Constitution to be amended so as to give to the Commonwealth control over trade and commerce?

Mr. LATHAM.-The honorable gentleman has managed to pack a good many problems into one question. As Attorney-General, I am not prepared to answer it, n or to suggest that there are any weaknesses in the legislation recently passed. I hope that it may prove successful, and I propose to enforce it to the limit of federal power. I have already stated in this House that it is desired to press this inquiry to the limit of legitimate federal power. At the present stage I do not accept the suggestion that this inquiry cannot be made unless the Commonwealth is able to secure the assent of one or more of the State Parliaments.It is intended at present to deal with the matter upon a federal basis, and to endeavour to make the inquiry effective.
PERFORMING RIGHT ROYAL COMMISSION.
Mr.NAIRN. - Has the Attorney-General yet received the report of the royal commission which inquired concerning the performing right operation in Australia?
Mr. LATHAM.- Mr. Justice Langer Owen has sent his report to the Government, and it will be considered at an early date.
TAXATION COMMISSION.

Mr. BEASLEY.-Will the Attorney-General present to the House a progress report setting out the cost to date of the royal commission which some time ago was appointed to inquire into the question of taxation, in view of the fact that it appears likely to function indefinitely?

Mr. LATHAM.- Mr. Justice Ferguson is acting without fee or reward. The work which is being done is most highly skilled, and will be of great potential benefit to the Commonwealth. I say " potential ", because the benefit is dependent upon agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. I shall look into the matter raised by the honorable member ; but, in connexion with this commission particularly, I doubt whether any useful purpose would be served by setting an accountant to work to find out the exact amount that has been spent up to the present moment.
RESIDENT MINISTER IN LONDON.
Cost of Office.
Mr. WARD.- Will the Attorney-General furnish to the House particulars of the total cost to date of the office of Resident Minister in London?
Mr. LATHAM.-No. The fullest information upon this matter will be available to honorable members when the Estimates are placed before Parliament.
EXPORTS TO GREAT BRITAIN.
Suggested Restrictions.

Mr. ROSEVEAR.- Has the Minister for Commerce noticed in the press the report of a speech by Major Elliot, Minister for Agriculture in the British Government, in which the following statement appears: -

Having regard to the increased supply of home produced milk now being diverted to manufacture, and the accumulated stocks on manufacturers' hands, he was going to ask the dominions as an emergency measurefor substantial reductions of imports of condensed whole and condensed skim milk, skimmed cream and milk powder.

Has the British Government made any advances in the direction indicated? I should also like to know what is the general attitude of the Government towards these continued requests for restrictions on the exports of dominion products to Great Britain, and whether the honorable gentleman considers that by the adoption of this attitude the British Government is observing the true spirit of the Ottawa agreement.

Mr. STEWART.-I have read the paragraph to which the honorable member has referred. Official confirmation of its contents is awaited, before a decision as to policy can be adopted. The restriction of the importation into Great Britain, of the items mentioned by the honorable member would affect Australia very little, because only negligible quantities of them are sent from this country to the United Kingdom.

Group3. - Items which were passed by the House of Representatives during 1932.
Postponed item 19, sub-items (a) (b) (Tobacco).
Division 2. - Tobacco and Manufactures Thereof.
Upon which Mr. Riordan had moved -
That the item be further postponed.

Mr.PROWSE (Forrest) [3.4].- No good purpose will be served by further postponing the consideration of this item. Honorable members have had ample time, since its postponement in March last, to make up their minds about these duties. If we were sitting as the board of directors of an ordinary commercial undercaking, we should be required to consider from every aspect the particular business in which we were concerned, and I suggest that, when we are dealing with the position of the Australian tobacco industry, we should be permitted to consider both import and excise duties at the same time. If the Chair and the Standing Order's would permit, it would not be too late, even now, to adopt this procedure, and thus save considerable time in debate. The Minister, surely, is in a position to indicate the probable amount of excise if the import duty of 3s. per lb. imposed under this item is agreed to. If he could inform us, possibly we should be able to save a great deal of time in the discussion on the excise duties when we are dealing with that portion of the Government's proposals. A deputation waited upon the Minister yesterday to put 'before him the views of the growers with regard to these duties. I do not know whether he 'considers that he has had sufficient time to determine his attitude to their requests.
Mr. White.- There has not been time, to consider all aspects of the requests made by the deputation.

Mr. PROWSE- It would greatly help the committee if the Minister could give an indication of the Government's attitude. In the course of his speech yesterday the Minister emphasized that the interests of the growers had been safeguarded 'by the action of the Government last year. No one will deny that the undertaking given by the manufacturers to purchase a stipulated proportion of the crop was more than fulfilled. They purchased a greater quantity of tobacco leaf than was provided for in their agreement with the Government, and, while the arrangement was of material assistance to this important primary industry for the one year, the continuance of such assistance was not promised for the future. When considering the protection necessary to enable other industries to become established, it has been customary for govern^ ments to take the long view. Apparently, tobacco-growing is expected to get into rtss stride almost immediately. Last year a deputation waited upon the former Minister for Trade and Customs, Sir Henry Gullett, to place before him the views of the growers, and in his reply the Minister said -

The Government was quite prepared, and had so indicated, to see that the full crop grown this year of sound marketable tobacco was purchased by the companies, and it intended to maintain the highest possible price. This would not be left to the companies to decide. If necessary, the Government would put an embargo on as a starting point, and then come to terms with the companies.
There, again, we have an undertaking to assist the industry for one year only.
Sir HenryGullett. - And it was carried out. .

Mr. PROWSE.-I have already admitted that; but the growers have been given no indication of the future position. The honorable member for Henty (Sir. Henry Gullett) speaking in this House on the 10th March, 1932, while he was still Minister for Trade and Customs, stated -

The Government favours a change-over (from American to Australian-grown tobacco) subject to the production of leaf of good quality capable of yielding to the Treasury an amount of revenue similar to that which, it is now yielding. . . .

The honorable gentleman was on sound1 lines on that occasion, and took the long range view. If that policy were given effect by the Government, I should', be perfectly satisfied. Like the honorable gentleman, I wish that the smokersof this country would change from theuse of American, to the use of Australian, tobacco, and I do not desire to see the change made at an expense of the revenue. This Government adheres fairly closely to the recommendations of the Tariff Board. On this subject the Tariff Board reported that-

It would he unwise during the period in which the Australian leaf-growing industry is becoming established to seek to increase the net revenue from tobacco beyond the amount received during 1929-30 - approximately £0,500,000.

I have said on previous occasions in this chamber that whether all the tobacco smoked is made from imported or local leaf, the revenue from it should be similar. This is essentially a revenue item. But the action of the Government has increased the revenue from tobacco by approximately £1,000,000 during the last year.
Mr. E.J. Harrison. - But will a similar amount be received from it this year?

Mr. PROWSE.-That is for the gods to determine. I do not think that the change over from American to Australian tobacco will affect the position. In the United States of America, where tobacco is indigenous, and has been grown perhaps longer than in any other country, the position of the industry is causing the Government considerable concern.
Sir HenryGullett. - The leaf is sold there for 6d. per lb.

Mr. PROWSE.-But it is produced at a loss. This led the Government of the United States of America to request t he tobacco-growers to restrict their production on the undertaking of the Government that, if they did so, the price would be increased by 25 per cent. We in Australia, on the other hand, are endeavouring to extract greater revenue than ever from the industry, although tobacco-growing in this country is in its infancy. I wish to make it clear to honorable members that I do not object to the obtaining of revenue from tobacco; but it should be obtained under reasonable conditions. For nearly seven weeks, we have been engaged in a tariff debate in this chamber, and the argument that has been used with success all along the line by the advocates of high duties, is that we must protect our manufacturers from the manufacturers of countries which employ black labour. I sincerely hope that there will be consistency in this respect in regard to this item. The American people consider that the tobacco industry is worth building up, and they are alarmed because the production of tobacco leaf hasbecome unprofitable. Last year a considerable quantity of tobacco made from Australian leaf was placed on the local market at 3s. per lb. less than the price asked for tobacco made from imported leaf. As a matter of fact, our smokers were able, only with difficulty, to obtain sufficient supplies of the local article. A very strong demand was made for tobacco made from Australian leaf. The local tobacco is, undoubtedly, improving in quality. It is well known to-day that 17s. 4d. per lb. is asked over the counter for imported tobacco. There is, therefore, a very big margin of profit even after substantial duties have been imposed. The objection to the tariff which the Government is now proposing is that it does not allow a sufficient margin of price to induce smokers to use the local article in preference to the imported article. One good effect which may come out of the action which the manufacturers are taking this year in placing the Australian leaf in store, is that it will mature and thus improve the quality of the tobacco made from it. The local manufacturers have not previously matured Australian leaf to any considerable extent. I am sure that the Australian smoker will suffer no disadvantage through acquiring a taste for Australian tobacco, for it is rapidly improving in quality. Many Australian smokers who think that they are smoking tobacco made from imported leaf are really smoking tobacco made from Australian leaf. Smokers who buy " Havelock Aromatic" tobacco may not have noticed an alteration in the lettering on the packets containing the tobacco. The words " Virginian leaf ", which formerly appeared on the packets, have been removed, the reason being, of course, that Australian leaf is now used. The tobacco industry is in a different category from any other, with the possible exception of the distillation of spirits. Tobacco is a narcotic, and the duty placed on it is purely a revenue duty. I submit that the Government is entitled to impose a sufficient duty on this article to cause it to yield the amount of revenue obtained from it prior to last year, but under conditions which will not make tobacco any more expensive to our smokers. I challenge honorable members to name any industry that we have built up in this country that can be compared with the tobacco industry. But I give an undertaking that, at all times, I will agree to a raising of the excise duty, as the local industry captures more and more of the Australian market.
Mr. White.- Why cut it down now ?

Mr. PROWSE- I have already given the reasons for my present attitude. The Minister must know that more revenue than was recommended by the Tariff Board has been received from this industry, and that very fact is reducing the prospects of the sale and use of Australian-grown tobacco. The people have acquired a liking for the locally-produced article, but a check has been placed upon the demand that was rapidly increasing.

When the price of Australian-grown tobacco closely approximates that of tobacco made from imported leaf, the public will judge the two sorts of tobacco solely upon their flavour, and will probably prefer the kind to which they have been accustomed for many years. If the excise duty were reduced to 3s. per lb., the margin would make possible the ready sale of local tobacco. Less than 6,000,000 lb. of leaf will be produced in this country next season.
Sir HenryGullett. - Is the honorable member sure of that?

Mr. PROWSE.-The quantity is likely to be less rather than more than I have mentioned. The fear of unfavorable legislation with regard to tobacco is one of the reasons why the production estimated for the coming season shows a heavy fall. Many growers have gone out of the industry. The past season has been unfavorable; frosts, in particular, having destroyed the prospects in many localities.
Mr. E.J. Harrison. - All the more reason why the excise duty should be kept up, so that the revenue shall not suffer

Mr. PROWSE.-If the import duty were 4s. 6d. per lb., the loss of revenue from imports would not nearly be covered by the excise revenue that the Tariff Board suggested should be derived from Australian leaf this year. The matter of the ' excise duty should be considered annually, and an adequate rate should be fixed, having regard to the quantity of locally-grown tobacco used in Australia.

The honorable member for Henty (Sir Henry Gullett') hopes that the day will come when Australian-grown leaf will supply the whole of this country's requirements of tobacco. In that event, the tariff would have to be adjusted in such a way as to meet the revenue needs of the country, as . suggested by the Tariff Board.

This year, the quantity of Australian-grown tobacco available will be limited.;' but it will keep the local article under the notice of smokers, and make possible the ultimate attainment of the objective of the honorable member for Henty, which is that all the tobacco used in this country should, be grown here. I am satisfied that the quality -of the tobacco manufactured from Australian leaf in the next twelve months will be superior to that made heretofore, for the simple reason that the manufacturers are allowing sufficient time for the leaf to mature before placing it on the market. This method should be followed year by year. I shall be glad if the Minister will indicate the real intentions of the Government. The com mittee desires definite information, and I am satisfied that it will take a reasonable view of the matter. I hope that the duty will not be left as it stands, for there should be some further advantage in the matter of excise. I trust that the matter will be dealt with promptly, and on non-party lines.

Sir HENRYGULLETT (Henty) [3.25]. - I cannot refrain from commenting on the remarkable change that has taken place since last year's debate on this item. I think that I may say that the whole lone of this discussion is entirely different from that of last year. The dismal forebodings as to the future, consequent upon the alteration of the duties a year ago, are not nearly so prominent in the present debate. As the Minister, who was responsible for the drastic change made last year, I should like to' acknowledge the almost unanimous, and! even generous, admission that that alteration has worked out extremely well for the' growers, at least so far as last year's crop is concerned. Having been sub'jected last year to bitter criticism, I much appreciate the admission from all parts of the House that the change was not a disastrous one, but, on the contrary, was highly beneficial. I take a bright view of the future, and, indeed, of the near future, of this industry in the Commonwealth. I believe that the problems and difficulties still confronting it are due entirely to its sudden development, and: are merely incidental to the transitionstage through which it is passing.

Two facts stand out clearly. The first is that the Commonwealth can, and will, produce all of its requirements " of tobacco, and, in my opinion, it will produce them at a very early date. The honorable member for Indi (Mr. Hutchinson) in an admirable, well informed and courageous speech, last night estimated that it would take the growers about ten years to capture the Australian market. Personally, I consider that if they watch their business closely, and work well, they will capture about 90 per cent, of the Australian market within the next four years at most. . Of course, it will always be necessary to import a quantity of tobacco for blending and flavouring purposes. The next fact that stands out clearly is that the local manufacturers admit that the Australian grower can produce sufficient leaf to meet this country's requirements of tobacco. That is a most significant admission. It was made clear last year that the local manufacturers, and particularly the British-Australasian Tobacco Company, entered into their huge undertaking for the purchase of the Australian crop in the belief that they were buying leaf that would produce a tobacco acceptable to the Australian smoker, and in the sure conviction that the quality of the locally-produced article would progressively improve, and, eventually, take the place of the imported Virginian leaf. If the local industry is to capture the market at an early date, two things are essential. First, there must be still further improvement of the quality of the leaf. Unquestionably, our highest grade leaf is equal to the best Virginian leaf: indeed, the one closely resembles the other. That similarity makes the change-over all the simpler for every one concerned. The first essential is that individual growers shall concentrate on the production of leaf of the highest possible quality. The second requirement is a complete overhaul of the organization controlling the industry. The Australian tobacco manufacturing companies undertook to purchase 7,250,000 lb. of leaf. Of that quantity the British-Australasian Tobacco Company agreed to buy 6,000,000 lb., but. instead, it bought nearly 8,500,000 lb. of leaf at an average price of 2s. 3d. per lb. Altogether, the various companies purchased between 10,000,000 lb. and 11,000,000 lb. of Australian leaf, and for all the leaf of first-class quality they paid the growers . more than 2s. 3d. per lb., the average being 2s. 3d. per lb. With a protection of 3s. per lb., which the present duty gives to them, Australian growers of good bright leaf are assured of a fair price in the future for their output up to a total national production of 20,000,000 lb. per- . annum. But for the grower of dark leaf I see nothing ahead but disaster. Any attempt to encourage the growth of such leaf is absolute madness. In my opinion, any honorable member who encourages growers to cultivate tobacco on rich river flats, which are likely to produce only dark and heavy leaf, is most unwise, and, indeed, unkind. As I have said, I predict that within three or four years Australia will produce from 18,000,000 lb. to 20,000,000 lb. of tobacco leaf, equal in quality to sound Virginian leaf. Any attempt to force either the manufacturers of tobacco, or the smokers of tobacco, to accept heavy dark leaf, would be most unwise. The Government should make it clear to the growers of dark leaf that there is no prospect but disaster ahead of them.

The tobacco-growing industry in Australia is poorly organized. There has been too much politics and not enough of business methods in it. There has been too great a desire to send deputations to Canberra in order to secure votes for the industry. Those concerned would have served the industry better had they set themselves to improve the industry from within, and to establish it on a sound basis. The inefficiency of the organization was shown clearly in its estimate of last year's crop. In March last year, when the tobacco harvest season was approaching, a deputation which waited on the Prime Minister (Mr. Lyons) and myself stated that the organization expected a total production of 5,000,000 lb. of tobacco leaf. Later, when the crop proved to have been a much heavier one, a representative of the growers endeavoured to explain the error by saying that the deputation had meant that the leaf would be 5,000,000 lb., and that excise would be paid on a greater quantity. The growers' officials informed us that the crop would certainly not exceed 7,000,000 lb. ; but when it was gathered it was found to be about double that quantity. The estimate of that deputation placed the Government in an exceedingly difficult position. It was almost impossible to enter into negotiations with the manufacturers on a satisfactory basis, because of the uncertainty regarding the amount of the crop which would be handled. We are now told- that this year's crop will not exceed 6,000,000 lb. I do not know what that estimate is worth. The position of the present Minister must be exceedingly difficult, because of the absence of anything like exact information. In order to obtain a more reliable estimate of last year's crop than was presented -to me by the deputation, I obtained an officer from the Development Branch of the Prime Minister's Department, and instructed him to proceed to the various tobacco-growing districts in order to make an estimate of the crop. He did so, and the result was most satisfactory. The estimate of the organization representing the growers was of no value whatever.

The honorable member for Forrest (Mr. Prowse) is not so full of dismal forebodings to-day regarding the future of this industry as he was twelve months ago. The honorable gentleman contrasted the attitude of the Australian Government towards the tobacco-growing industry with that of the Government of the United States of America. He said that in the United States of America the growers of tobacco were subsidized by means of a bounty on the tobacco they produced, whereas the industry in Australia was loaded with an excise duty of 4s. 6d. per lb. I remind the honorable member that last year the American tobacco-grower received only 6d. per lb. on the ground for his leaf, whereas Australian growers of all tobacco, other than rubbish, were paid an average of 2s. 3d. per lb. for their crop, and in the previous year, 3s. per lb. Whatever the Commonwealth Government may, or may not, be doing to assist the tobacco-growing industry, the Australian smoker certainly subsidizes the growers of tobacco to the extent of from 100 per cent, to 150 per cent, of the value of his leaf. Speaking of the great value of the industry to Australia, the honorable member for New England (Mr. Thompson) said that last year's crop was worth £1,250,000. That, possibly, was the cost to Australian smokers of tobacco, but the leaf they consumed could have been imported- for about £500,000, including exchange and primage duty. It will therefore be seen that Australian smokers of tobacco paid to the local growers of the leaf a bounty of about £750,000 in respect of last year's crop. Australian tobacco-growers receive from 100 per cent, to 200 per cent, more for their leaf than is paid to any other tobacco-gro wers in the world.

I wish this industry well. Its pioneers are deserving of praise for the way in which they have persevered in order to improve the standard - particularly during the past three or four years. I speak not of the new men who have rushed in to' grow tobacco on unsuitable land while the going was good, but of those who have been longer in the industry. To these pioneers Australia owes a debt of gratitude.

The subject of revenue has again cropped up. I do not wish to transgress the Standing Orders, but it is difficult to dissociate a discussion of the duty from references to excise or revenue. If I may quote a precedent last year, the honorable member for Darwin (Mr. Bell), as Chair man of Committees, allowed the debate to range over the whole subject. It has been claimed that the forecast made by the Government last year as to the revenue which would result from the duty on tobacco has been falsified hy results. It is true that the Government then budgeted for something like £6,500,000 from this source, and that it now appears that the amount will be exceeded by approximately £600,000. The explanation is a- perfectly simple one, and was given by the honorable member for Indi (Mr. Hutchinson) in his excellent speech last night. When the Government caine to make its agreement with the Australian tobacco manufacturers, who, with the growers'" organizations, had not the vaguest idea of- the growers' crop anticipations, it was found that the manufacturers had entered into contracts and actually paid for something like 9,000,000 lb. of Virginian leaf, which, as an act of common justice the Government gave the manufacturers permission to import. That leaf has been brought into Australia within the past year, and a duty of 3s per lb. has been paid upon it; I have no doubt, that : ah- additional. 4s. 6d. per lb. excise has. been paid on portion of it. To .those circumstances only is the swollen revenue- -for .-.the ;year attributable. -I doubt that the imports of tobacco from the United States of America will exceed 2,0.00,000 or 3,000,000 lb. during the coming, year.; so. that a heavy shrinkage in the revenue from that source must be expected.

My reply to the contention of the honorable member for Forrest is that he should take not only one year, but an average over two or three years, when estimating what would have been the result had the Government not entered into its agreement with the manufacturers. Assuming that last year's crop amounted to 12,000,000 lb., it would have represented a total loss of revenue to the Government of £3,000,000, at the old duty of 5s. 2d. per lb., which, while it would not have occurred in any one twelve months, would have been suffered during the Government's period of office. It was that which was the great impelling force behind the Government's action.

In conclusion, if I may be so vain, I repeat a statement that I made a year ago ; I look forward keenly to the development of the tobacco industry in Australia, and I am sure that that is the attitude of the Government. But that desire is qualified 'by the condition that the tobacco industry must continue to contribute heavily to the revenue of the country. The industry is of incomparably greater importance to the Government of the country as a revenue producer than it is to our tobacco-growers as a source of income. Last year's crop added to the wealth of growers approximately £500,000, while as a revenue producer tobacco has contributed about £7,000,000 to the exchequer. We cannot afford, by a change, either of excise or duty, materially to affect that position. The present rate of duty is 3s. per lb, and the excise 4s. 6d. per lb. There is a proposal to reduce the rate of excise on Australian leaf in some way. How that is to be done only on Australian loaf I do not know, and I leave the problem to wiser and shrewder heads than mine. It is insisted by the honorable m'ember for New England, and every other honorable member agrees with him, that Australian leaf is now approximately as- good as the best imported leaf, and will ultimately take the place of . the latter; also, that there is no limit to .the quantity of first-class leaf that can be grown in Australia. Accepting that contention, ' it is surely no hardship to the growers if our leaf has to carry an excise duty of 4s.' 6d. per lb., when the American leaf, which finds a ready consumption in Australia, bears a total impost of 7s. Cd. per lb. Those who urge the case of the growers cannot have it both ways. If the Australian leaf - is as good as the American leaf, it should readily carry an equal impost. It is being let off lightly by being subjected to an impost of 3s. per lb. less than the American ; also, that amount' is lost to the Treasury. The Australian grower has fallen on his feet ; the market is his if he grows good leaf, and there should be no objection to his product carrying an excise of 4s. 6d. per lb.
Mr. Riordan.- What is the difference between the standard of living of the negro who produces tobacco in the United States of America and that of the white Australian producer?

Sir HENRYGULLETT.- The honorable member's question has no bearing on the point that I am making. I have already pointed out that, while tobacco growers in the United States of America are receiving only 6d. per lb. and white growers in Canada 8d. per lb. for their leaf, Australian growers are being paid 2s. 3d. per lb. for their product. I do not know what arrangement the Minister has made for the current year, but I trust that it will be satisfactory to the growers.
Mr. White.- The manufacturers will buy all the good leaf that is available.
Sir HENRYGULLETT.- I do not press to be told the price at this juncture ; but, obviously, it enters largely into the matter.

Mr. THOMPSON(New England) [3.48]. - The statements made by the honorable member for Henty (Sir Henry Gullett) are not difficult to answer. I appreciate the tone of cordiality that the honorable gentleman now adopts towards the industry, although I well remember the time when he said in this chamber that good tobacco could not be grown in Australia.
Sir HenryGullett. - I said no such thing. The honorable member forForrest (Mr. Prowse) has quoted me to the contrary this afternoon.

Mr. THOMPSON.-The honorable member declared that we cannot proceed with the proposed amendment of the excise duty on bright leaf because, if our leaf is as good as that from the United States of America, it should carry a similar impost. The honorable gentleman knows very well that at present only a very small portion of bright leaf is being produced in Australia which is equal to the imported product.
Sir HenryGullett.- The proportion is 40 per cent.

Mr. THOMPSON.-That refers to bright mahogany; but the honorable gentleman was speaking of bright leaf comparable with that from the United States of America. The fact that we are producing such a small quantity of bright leaf indicates that greater encouragement should be given to the growers to place more first-class leaf on the market. The tariff alteration which was brought about by the honorable gentleman has driven a great quantity of Australian tobacco off the market, and I am safe in saying that the demand for Australian tobacco has decreased by 50 per cent. since that alteration was made. My colleagues and I want to rectify that position, and reinstate our product on the market. Once the market is recaptured, and imports are shut out, satisfactory arrangements can be made to meet the Government's requirements with regard to excise duty. The honorable member made capital of the fact that the organization was so ill informed that it misled him last year about the quantity of tobacco produced. He should know that the estimate upon which the Tobacco Growers Association worked, and which was furnished to him, was obtained from the Commonwealth Tobacco Investigation attached to the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research. The fact that the estimate was wrong is no reflection on the growers' organization, which obviously cannot keep track of all the growers in Australia, and the quantity they produce. It is. however, a serious reflection on the State organizations which are supposed to be controlling the industry, not to be able to furnish all the information desired. It also proves that there is no effective liaison between the Commonwealth Tobacco Investigation and the State departments of agriculture in regard to tobacco. This was proved by evidence tendered to the committee of inquiry of which I was chairman. It is a weakness which neither the Commonwealth nor State authorities have attempted to rectify.

The honorable member spoke of the heavy subsidy paid by the people of Australia to the industry, and quoted the sum of£1,250,000 paid in cash last year for Australian leaf. That, he said, was proof that our smokers had been very generous to the local growers. I remind him, however, that before one-tenth of the present annual crop was being produced in Australia, smokers were being charged practically the same prices as now. The smokers had to pay the same amount whether the money went to the growers or not. Of course, we know that, actually, it went to the tobacco combine, which has been making profits of £1,000,000 a year, paying bonuses of 40 per cert. to its shareholders, and watering its capital as well.
Last night the Minister spoke of a proposed agreement for the purchase of this year's crop, or am I right in assuming that it is to be an agreement?
Mr. White.- The buyers made a generous offer; it will not be an agreement.

Mr. THOMPSON.-It would be a very serious thing for the industry if an arrangement of the kind mentioned by the Minister were made. He said that the manufacturers did not propose to buy this year any tobacco of a quality below bright mahogany. That would exclude mahogany and lower grades, so that there would be no sale for half the crop. I asked him three times during the course of his speech what price was to be offered, but he did not answer me. Even if the manufacturers agreed to take a reasonably large quantity of the leaf grown, they might not offer more than 6d. per lb. for it.
Mr. White.- The manufacturers cannot say what price they will give for the leaf untilthey have seen it.
Mr. THOMPSON.-Last year they offered 2s. 3d. per lb. before they had seen it.
Mr. White.-And they over-bought by a great deal.

Mr. THOMPSON.-The manufacturers' offer for this year's crop is of no use to the growers, having regard to the present duties. If the manufacturers are really going to buy only the grades mentioned by the Minister, they will exclude practically 60 per cent. of the Australian crop.
Mr. White.- I said that they would buy as much of the dark leaf as would be needed to replace what was used last year.

Mr. THOMPSON.- That is not a very helpful offer, because they are using only a small quantity of dark leaf now. If the manufacturers are prepared to take only a limited quantity of leaf, they might as well say so, and not make stipulations regarding the grades they will buy. If they pay 2s. 3d. per lb. for the high grades, and turn down all grades below bright, the average price will be only about1s. l1/2d. per lb. for the whole crop, and it is impossible to grow tobacco profitably with white labour at that price. The manufacturers' offer, if adhered to, will do even more to injure the industry than the recent tariff alterations.

Reference has been made to the report of Mr. Marks, senior agronomist to the Commonwealth Tobacco Investigation, in regard to a request I made for an inquiry by an officer of his department into complaints by growers in the Tamworth, Manila, and other districts, that large quantities of leaf had been left on their hands. The report seemed to afford considerable pleasure to some honorable members opposite, and I was sorry to see that they took such delight in the fact that the case I had put forward seemed to be so overwhelmingly refuted by this official. I stated that, in my opinion, the combine was victimizing growers in the districts which I represent, including Tamworth, Manila, Scone, and other places. I said that I had been told by growers that the buyers, after refusing to purchase leaf, had. said, "You have to blame your Federal member, Mr. Thompson, for this ". I never heard of one instance in which the buyers, (after agreeing to take a crop, had told the grower that he should thank his Federal member for it. One of the complainants was the president of the

Northern Tobacco Growers Association, Mr. Parkes, who accompanied Mr. Marks in the course of his investigations. After I had heard the complaints, I decided that I was called upon to take some action, and I took it in the only way available to me. I have also received complaints that the State tobacco expert, apparently aided and abetted by the State Department of Agriculture, was neglecting the district I represented, because the growers at various meetings had expressed dissatisfaction at his control of the industry. I pointed out that the expert was going around with the combine's buyer, and discussing with him whether the leaf should be purchased or not. I contended that that was the job of the buyers, and not of the State tobacco expert. Another complaint made by me was that the tobacco combine had been for many years hostile to the Tamworth district, because it is the oldest tobacco-growing district in Australia. There the agitation for the establishment of the Australian industry originated, and I have not the slightest doubt that, but for the white pioneer growers in the Tamworth district, the cultivation of tobacco in Australia would not have advanced as it has. done. I do not question the bona fides of Mr. Marks. I know him fairly well, and I am satisfied that he knows a good deal about the cultivation of tobacco ; but I question the methods he adopted in the preparation of the report quoted by the Minister. Only a Philadelphia lawyer could ascertain from the document what he means, and I shall be surprised if anybody is able to discover whether he is expressing his own opinions or those of the British-Australasian Tobacco Company. He refers to Chinese growers in such a way as to give the impression that all the tobacco produced in the Tamworth district is grown by Chinese. A departmental officer instructed to carry out an investigation of this sort should be able to analyse the evidence, weigh all the facts, and furnish a report that would be intelligible to Parliament. I say, with all respect to Mr. Marks' qualifications as a tobacco expert, that he is incapable of writing an understandable report. He has not stated how many Chinese are engaged in growing tobacco in the Tamworth district.
Mr. White.- I stated that I have information that 52 per cent. of the growers with unsold tobacco are Chinese.

Mr. THOMPSON.- That may or may not be true. If it istrue, half of the growers, who have not sold their tobacco in the Tamworth district last season, are white men. The impression should not be created that all the growers in the Tamworth district are Chinese. In any case, I do not know that the White Australia ideal is menacedmore by Chinese than by negroes. The very men who are so indignant regarding Chinese tobacco-growers are fighting tooth and nail for American negroes, who grow 90 per cent. of the tobacco imported into Australia. I am not contending for a Chinese industry; actually, only 1 per cent. of those engaged in the cultivation of tobacco throughout Australia are Chinamen, and there is nothing alarming in that state of affairs. With the exception of an occasional storekeeper, the Chinese growers in the Tamworth district do not own the land they are cultivating. They are merely labourers, some of whom have been growing tobacco in the district for 40 or 50 years. They do not cure the leaf; that is done by white men. The fact must not be forgotten that, for many years, the Chinese were the only growers of tobacco in Australia. After the combine had killed the tobacco-growing industry in Victoria, practically the only growers left in Australia for about twenty years were a few Chinese in the Tamworth and Texas districts. They produced large quantities of dark, heavy leaf, which they could afford to sell at a low price, but as the quality rose and fluecuring was introduced, the market for their product disappeared. Those honorable members who profess so much concern about the Chinese engaged in the cultivation of tobacco should also protest against the use of vegetables grown by Chinese,and against the smoking of tobacco produced by American negroes. The essence of Mr. Marks' report seems to be a chart, and I find it impossible to discover whether it is based on information collected by him or on information supplied by the British-Australasian Tobacco Company. Undoubtedly, similar information was supplied by the company to Mr. Mark's officein Canberra. He states in his report -
Reference to the accompanying chart will show that of the 4,344 bales rejected by the British-Australasian Tobacco Company, the analysis gives only 8 per cent. of usable leaf.

The only authority that could furnish that chart was the British-Australasian Tobacco Company. The Minister stated some time ago that the manufacturers had informed him that less than 10 per cent. of the leaf grown in the Tamworth district was usable, and even that was not worth more than 3d. per lb. Mr. Marks now quotes from a chart which supports the Minister's statement. The 4,344 bales would represent about 400 tons of tobacco, and it is physically impossible for any man to check that quantity, and analyse it in the detail shown in Mr. Marks' report in the brief period he spent in the district. His estimate includes such details as - inferior bright, . 9 per cent. ; mahogany, 65 per cent.; mahogany, good, 2.4 per cent. ; and mahogany, medium strong, 4.6 per cent. If Mr. Marks were able personally to examine and assess 400 tons of tobacco in such detail he is a magician; he should not now be wasting his time as an agronomist, but should be Prime Minister of Australia. I knew that I was taking a risk when I asked that an officer be sent to the Tamworth district to report on the quantities of unsold leaf left with the growers. There is a curious readiness on the part of both Commonwealth and State officers to decry Australian tobacco producers. The Select Committee on the Tobacco Industry found that most of the expert witnesses had so many reservations that their evidence was worthless. Each official who came before us with preconceived ideas showed that he was prepared to make reservations about everything, and even retract all that he had said. If Mr. Marks had made a fair report, and said that a lot of the unsold tobacco leaf in the Tamworth district was bad, I would not have objected, because I know that much of it is inferior.
Mr. White.- The honorable member said last night that all of it was suitable for manufacture.
Mr. THOMPSON.-I say that all of it is usable.
Mr. White.- For what ?

Mr. THOMPSON.- For some purpose in connexion with the manufacture of tobacco. I knew that much of the leaf unsold was quite inferior, but the statement that of the 400 tons fully 90 per cent. is unfit for any use is outrageous. That assertion cannot be substantiated by Mr. Marks, and I should like to test it with the evidence of the growers before an independent authority.
Mr.Lane. - Why not the officers of the State department?

Mr. THOMPSON.- Mr. Marks'report proves that the Tamworth growers have been shockingly neglected by the State department, and that they have considerable ground for believing that they have been victimized. He attributes the inferiority of much of the tobacco to the fact that those controlling the industry in New South Wales have been neglectful of this district. The growers are now left with 400 tons of tobacco, representing all their capital, and they should be afforded an opportunity to prove that the statements of Mr. Marks are wrong, and that he has merely followed in the footsteps of the BritishAustralasian Tobacco Company. I shall forward a copy of the report to the growers in my district who, I am sure, will communicate to the Government their dissatisfaction with it. They will prove that it represents wholly the opinion of the buyers of the British-Australasian Tobacco Company, and that the chart employed by Mr. Marks was one prepared by that company. I am personally convinced that the chart was taken from the records of the British-Australasian Tobacco Company. In no other way could the information have been obtained in a brief period. Mr. Marks has mishandled his job; he has certainly adopted the wrong methods, and reported incompetently. The jobhe professes to have done is too big for one man to have done in the time available, and I ask the Government to refer the matter to some independent authority for further investigation.
Mr.Lane. - Suggest somebody.

Mr. THOMPSON.-I cannot, offhand, suggest any person who is qualified to undertake this inquiry. I am disappointed that Mr. Marks did not deal justly with the growers. He has gone much too far in his sweeping condemna tion of the tobacco grown in the district, and that is proved by the fact that 600 tons of that tobacco were actually purchased by the manufacturers at an average price of 2s. 3d. per lb.
Mr.Nock. - That is not mentioned in Mr. Marks' report.

Mr. THOMPSON.- That is so. Mr. Marks has not carried out his job properly. He should have given verse and chapter in his reasons for damning the district, but that he was not able to do. For most of his information he was dependent upon data furnished to him by the British- Australasian Tobacco Company. The growers will probably instruct their representatives to wait on the Ministar in order to refute some of these statements. I do not say that the 400 tons of tobacco which is still left in the district is all good tobacco, but it is absolutely wrong to contend that it is 90 per cent. bad. Neither Mr. Marks nor theBritishAustralasian Company could stand up to that statement under cross-examination by persons who are competent to deal with the matter. If the Minister requires any further information from the growers I shall be pleased to supply it to him. I hope that in view of the misunderstandings and difficulties which have arisen during the course of this debate, the Government will accept the amendment of the honorable member for Kennedy (Mr. Riordan) to postpone the item, at least for a few days until we can decide whether it is possible to adopt some other policy which will be beneficial to the growers, and put a stop to the turmoil which is now developing in the industry, at the same time assisting the Government to extricate itself from a tight corner.

Mr.RIORDAN (Kennedy) [4.17]. - I wish to point out to the members of the Country party and other honorable members representing tobacco-growing areas that if they carry this item as it stands, in the hope of altering the excise duty when the excise schedule is before the committee, I am afraid that any opportunity to assist the growers and those engaged in the tobacco industry will be lost to them. My amendment aims at the restoration of the. margin of protection established by the Scullin Government, which was an import duty of 5s. 2d. per lb., and an excise duty in respect of tobacco manufactured from both Australian and foreign leaf. As I cannot move for an increase of duty because of the fact that any alteration of the rates would affect the revenue of the Common- wealth, I have moved that the item be postponed. The Acting Leader of the Country party (Mr. Paterson) has stated that he intends to support the Government in opposing my amendment, on the ground that the item can be dealt with when the excise schedule is before the committee. The honorable member must know that we cannot deal with this item during the discussion of the excise schedule.
Mr. Thorby.- Any member can move for a reduction of the excise duty.
Mr. RIORDAN.- No member can move an amendment providing for a reduction of the excise duty, because, if carried, it would affect the revenue of the Commonwealth.
Mr. Thorby.- An amendment to reduce the excise duty could be moved in committee.

Mr,. RIORDAN.- It could not. If we pass this item as it stands, there will be no opportunity given to us to move for a reduction of excise duty of, say, ls. 6d. per lb., the consequent loss in revenue to be . made up by an increase of. the import duty. Yesterday the honorable member for Forrest (Mr. Prowse), by interjection, indicated that he proposed to support the amendment. Since then the Government, realizing that it was likely to be defeated on this item, has evidently approached the Country party for support, because the Acting Leader of that party has now adopted an attitude quite different from that of one . of his own colleagues who seconded the amendment, and who was chairman of the select committee which inquired into the tobacco industry. The honorable member for Gippsland has left his colleague high and dry. Last night the Postmaster-General (Mr. Parkhill) said that there was no true ring about the amendment and the arguments of those who were advocating that additional protection should be given to the industry. Since this Government has been in office the members of the Labour party ' and other honorable members have been continually fighting on behalf of the tobacco-growers.

Protests have . been forwarded to the Minister for Trade and Customs, and deputations have waited upon the Prime Minister, the previous Minister for Trade and Customs, and the present Minister. Telegrams have been sent to practically every honorable member, asking him to make a stand in the interests of the tobacco-growers. It has been stated that the growers are quite content with the present rate of duty. That statement is not correct. The growers must have some 'reason for complaint, otherwise they would not go to the expense of sending delegations to Canberra. I say definitely that the growers are not satisfied with the existing tariff protection. The Minister has stated that the Mareeba growers were opposed to the renewal of last year's agreement, but it is evident that the secretary of the Mareeba Growers Association, who is an accountant, and its president, who is an agent, have been fed by the manufacturers with their propaganda in opposition to a renewal of the agreement under which they guaranteed to purchase up to 8,000,000 lb. of leaf at an average price of 2s. 3d. per lb. There was nothing wrong with that agreement, and no one had any complaint to make about it. The manufacturers honoured it, because they bought 10,000,000 lb. of leaf at an average price of 2s. 3d. per lb. They purchased 2,000,000 lb. of leaf over and above the quantity that they undertook to buy. Some of that tobacco sold in and around Mareeba brought up to 3s. 9d. per lb. When visiting a few of the factories in the capital cities, I noticed that some of the tobacco which the manufacturers had purchased had been badly banded and packed, and was not really worth the price paid for it. The agreement did not compel the manufacturers to buy that class of tobacco, but, nevertheless, they honoured the agreement. The restriction of imports gave security to the .growers, but since the termination of the agreement, the manufacturers have suddenly discovered that a disease known as " spotty leaf " has broken out in North Queensland. While the agreement was in existence, the manufacturers tried to persuade the Mareeba growers that there was no need to renew it, because, in any case, they would buy the whole of the tobacco leaf at favorable prices. They also contended that tobacco leaf was being grown in unsuitable areas. I admit that some persons began to grow tobacco in unsuitable areas, but, from the outset, their efforts were doomed to failure. That took place even in Queensland. In that State, i be growers have had the benefit of instruction from agricultural experts. The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research has established an experimental station at Mareeba, where instruction can be obtained in the cultivation of tobacco leaf, and the selection of land and seed. The growers in that district are producing a leaf which I am satisfied can be marketed Much of the work in the tobacco growing industry is seasonal, and one great advantage is that it provides employment in Queensland during the slack period of the sugar industry, which is between December and April. This industry is deserving of protection for that reason alone. The Minister said that he had received from a trade source the information that spotty leaf was prevalent in the Mareeba district. It is a peculiar circumstance that the honorable gentleman should rely on information from a trade source when the Commonwealth has in Mareeba a tobacco expert who could supply, within an hour or an hour and a half, any information that it desired. A reliable informant would be Mr. Howell, who is in charge of the experimental station at Mareeba.

The honorable member for Henty (Sir Henry Gullett) said that he was pleased that the hostility displayed towards the proposals of the Government was not so marked on the present occasion as when bc was Minister for Trade and Customs. T assure him that it is quite as great. It, should be greater, because, although lie was responsible for the reduction of the duty, he at least took steps to protect, the industry during the marketing of last season's crop, by limiting imports and securing a price for the growers. The present Minister says that the companies undertake to purchase this year all the bright leaf produced and Mahogany No. 2 to the extent of the quantity of dark tobacco manufactured by them this year. From 25 per cent, to 30 per cent, of the drop will be light leaf. I do not know what quantity of dark leaf was handled by the company. Assuming, however, that its purchases last year totalled 12,000,000 lb., if they take only the light leaf this year the quantity disposed of by the growers will be not greater than 4,000,000 lb. Therefore, unless the effect of the Government's policy has been to lessen the production by '8,000,000 lb. on last year's figures, the balance will be left without a market, and there is no guarantee that it will be sold. The Minister said that the companies have bought two years ahead. I point out that it is necessary to store Australian tobacco for two years, so that it may mature sufficiently before the manufacturing stage is entered upon. The reason for the failure to have the agreement renewed is the low price of tobacco in the United States of America. The Australian growers have no guarantee in regard to prices, and cannot be sure that more than a comparatively small proportion of the leaf grown will be purchased. No difficulty will be experienced in marketing the Mareeba crop, because it is a good quality leaf which finds a ready sale at a price about ls. or ls. 3d. per lb. higher than that paid for the leaf produced in other districts. A lighter crop to the acre' is produced, but the quality is that which is demanded by smokers.

The honorable member for Henty referred to the subsidy paid by smokers to the growers of tobacco. There is practically no difference between the pricetoday and that which ruled in 1929, before any protection was given to the industry. Up to three or four weeks ago. one could purchase fine cut Champion tobacco in Melbourne for ls. 6d. or ls. 7d. a 2-oz. packet. To-day the imported manufactured tobacco is ls. 9d. a 2-oz. packet. QLD tobacco, which is equal to the imported, can be bought for ls. 9d. a 2-oz. packet in Sydney. The honorable member for Henty says that the smoker pays a subsidy on Australian-grown leaf. Is that not preferable to paying a subsidy on that grown by the .coolie or the negro, who to-day is receiving 6d. per lb., and who last year did not get sufficient to defray the cost of the gasoline used in transporting his crop to market.

In 1930-31 the Australian crop was less than 2,000,000 lb., and although in that year more, than 3,000,000 lb. of Australian leaf was used in manufacture, compared with less than 1,000,000 lb. in 1928-29, still the great demand for Australian tobacco in 1931 could not be supplied. In addition to a great improvement in quality - an all important factor - it was comparatively low in price. The import duty was then 5s. 2d. per lb., but the consumer of the local article was able to purchase it for 5s. per lb. less than imported tobacco. No attempt was made to exploit the protection afforded. The excise duty on tobacco then was 2s. 4d. per lb., making the combined duty on imported tobacco 7s. 6d. per IB. The duty on tobacco leaf entering the United Kingdom is 9s. 6d. per lb., and there is no local industry there to protect. The net result of the last alterations made in tobacco duties was to leave the combined duty on imported tobacco unaltered, but to increase the duty on Australian tobacco by 93 per cent.; from 2s. 4d. to 4s. 6d. per lb. One immediate result was an increase in the price of Australian tobacco, with a marked decline in the consumption of it. Manufacturers freely admitted that their inability to supply the demand for Australian tobacco in 1931 was due to the limited supplies of local leaf. Growers set out to make up the shortage, but before the first big crop was harvested the duties were drastically altered.

The value of the Australian crop in J 929-30 was £92,000, and in 1931-32, well over £1,000,000 - some estimate it as high as £1,250,000. In 1929-30, the value of foreign leaf imported was £1,76S,000, and in 1931-32, £575,000. The beneficial effect to Australia will be seen by comparing these figures. Directly and indirectly, thousands of workers obtained employment who otherwise must have remained on the dole.

In 1929-30, only 6 per cent, of the tobacco leaf manufactured locally was grown in Australia. A federal parliamentary select committee, after an exhaustive inquiry into the industry early in 1930, found that the then tariff protection of 3s. per lb. was inadequate. It recommended an increase, and the Government gave it, with the results stated. Towards the end of 1931, the Tariff

Board inquired into the industry. No tobacco farms were visited, and only a very small number of growers gave evidence. The board's report proposed " crushing competition." In the report, at page 12, is this amazing statement -

The board has already pointed out that the quantity of Australian-grown leaf will continue to increase unless the industry is exposed to crushing competition by the removal of the duty or its reduction to a figure thai will not constitute adequate protection.

Growers feel that by leaving the combined duty on imported tobacco unaltered, and increasing the duty on Australian tobacco by 93 per cent., a crushing blow has been dealt to the local industry. They seek a revision of the present duties in such a way as will enable Australian tobacco to be put on the market at a price well below that of imported, and in this direction urge a substantial reduction in the excise on Australian tobacco. This would again stimulate the consumption of the local article and the purchase of Australian-grown leaf. A strong deputation waited on the Prime Minister and the Minister for Trade and Customs last year, and requested a differential rate of excise - 3s. 4d. on Australian tobacco and 5s. 4d. on imported. The request was not granted. There are other alternative schemes which could be considered. One is for a reversion to the 1931 duties, with progressive increases in excise to make good any loss in revenue resulting from a decline in the volume of imports. Another scheme suggested provides for a compromise between the 1931 duties and those now operating as follows: - 1931 duties, import, 5s. 2d.; excise, 2s. 4d.; margin, 5s. 2d.; present duties, import, 3s. ; excise, 4s. 6d. ; margin, 3s. ; suggested duties, import, 4s. 6d.; excise, 3s.; margin, 4s. 6d.

The adoption of these suggested rates might be acceptable to all parties. The required, revenue would be forthcoming. The price of imported tobacco would not be increased. The price of Australian tobacco would be lowered, and there would be no administrative difficulty. I have received from E. S. and B. C. Moulton Limited, a letter referring to an exhibit which they staged at the recent Royal Agricultural Show in Sydney. They had as a backcloth to their stand a life-size replica of a sign which depicted Uncle Sam standing behind a gate, on which appeared the words, "U.S. Customs". Above the figures were printed the ' words, " Would they allow our tobacco into Virginia?" That is a fair question for Australians to ask. Negro-grown tobacco is allowed to enter Australia, and, unfortunately, many Australians purchase the imported in preference to their own tobacco, even though the price is the same. Economic circumstances, of course, compel many persons to. buy the cheapest article, no matter where it comes from. Up to date, however, most of our tobaccos have been sold at the same price as that charged for imported tobacco, although the Mareeba tobacco manufactured in Brisbane is 2d. a 2-oz. tin dearer than imported tobacco. Australian tobacco cannot be marketed at a higher price because of the extent of unemployment, rationing, and relief work, which makes it necessary for housewives to watch every penny and to buy in the cheapest market, no matter how strongly imbued they may be with the Australian sentiment. The honorable member for Henty said that there would be a shrinkage in imports this year. I point out that the quantity of foreign leaf imported into Victoria over a period of six months in 1932 was greater than for the. corresponding period in 1931. Imports have been flowing into that State while low prices have existed in the United States of America; the importers have filled their stores and made provision for next year, and the tobacco producer of this country must get along as he may.
