The honorable member for Henty also made the statement that the combine would be prepared to buy all good leaf. Who is to be the judge whether leaf is good or bad? The grower naturally says that his leaf is good, and the buyer seeks to depreciate the quality so as to obtain it at a lower price. In the last analysis, the buyer becomes the) judge, because of circumstances over which the grower has no control.

The reason given by the Country party for again sidestepping the issue is, that it can accomplish some measure of reform by means of an excise duty of 4s. 6d. per lb. on foreign-grown tobacco, and .of 3s. per lb. on Australian-grown leaf. Do the members of that party really hope to get anything from the Government, or has the Government changed its policy in regard to the excise duty? Last year the then Minister for Trade and Customs said that he did not think it would be possible for the Government to have two different excise duties, one on foreign-grown and the other on , locally-grown leaf. He argued that a new department would be required to police the matter if such a practice were adopted. He referred the question to the Comptroller-General of

Customs, whose opinion was that even if it were not impossible to have two different excise duties operating, such a scheme would be extraordinarily difficult and complicated to administer.' Replying to the deputation which waited upon him at that time, the honorable gentleman said -

The Government was quite prepared, and had so indicated, to see that the full crop ' grown this year of sound marketable tobacco waa purchased by' the companies, and it intended to maintain the highest possible price. This would not be left for the companies to decide. If necessary, the Government would put an embargo on as a starting point, and then come to terms with the companies.

The Government could take action along those lines to-day. The Minister, I admit, has the power to keep out imports by means of an embargo. If an embargo were put on - and it is strongly advocated by a number of growers' associations - much, of the leaf not now regarded by buyers as sound and marketable would quickly become so. Growers desire to know where they stand in regard to the portion of last season's marketable leaf still unsold, and also in regard to the disposal of this year's crop. Although the 1932 Australian crop was' over 12,000,000 lb. - some estimate it as high as 14,000,000 lb. - compared with less than 2,000,000 lb. in 1931, importations of foreign leaf still flow in freely. The Victorian crop in 1932 was five or six times that of 1931, and still more foreign leaf entered Victoria for the six months ended December, 1932, than for the corresponding period of 1931. In 1930 and 1931 there was a glut of leaf in the United States of America, with rock-bottom prices prevailing. In 1929, the average landed cost of American bright leaf was ls. 6d. per lb. To-day it is about 6d. per lb. It is considered imperative that drastic restrictions, if not an embargo, should be placed on the importations of this leaf into Australia. Even in America, a move is being made to have an embargo placed on the importation of a type of loaf from Sumatra which is adversely affecting the local product. With the Australian market assured to local growers, a large sum of money, instead of being sent to America each year for tobacco leaf, will be retained in Australia, providing employment in this country. Contrast America's policy with the attitude of the Sydney Royal Agricultural Society recently towards the Brisbane firm of E. S. and E. C. Moulton Limited, which desired to advertise the Australian tobacco industry at the last Sydney show. The following letter, written by the firm mentioned, to the society, is self-explanatory: -

We desire to bring under your notice the circumstances surrounding an incident that occurred during the Royal Agricultural Show in Sydney. As distributors for the Associated Tobacco Manufacturers Proprietary Limited, of Brisbane, who manufacture a high class Australian tobacco, we staged an exhibit in the Industrial Hall at the Show, and, as a backcloth to our stand, a life-size replica of the above sign whs erected.
The sign mentioned was an. illustration of Uncle Sam barring the entrance of Australian tobacco into Virginia -
The Royal Agricultural Society took exception to this sign and ordered its removal in the following terms: -

There is a sign on your stand which, in the opinion of the society, is not in keeping with the standard of commercial and international impartiality we endeavour to maintain. The sign and picture we complain of . . . refers to the entry of Australian tobacco into Virginia, and I must ask you to have same removed or covered in some way.
The CHAIRMAN.- The honorable member has exhausted his time.

Mr. GIBSON(Corangamite) [4.48].- I am sorry that the Minister for Trade and Customs (Mr. White) did not see h*is way clear to allow the excise duty to he debated during the discussion on this item, because I feel sure that the debate on excise will be simply a repetition of this discussion, and will probably occupy some days which could be more profitably devoted to the consideration of other important subjects. Tobacco-growing is a comparatively new industry in Australia, at all events as regards the cultivation of leaf for smoking purposes. But 75 years ago tobacco of a kind was grown in considerable quantities in this country, particularly in Victoria. Cultivation methods in those days were similar to those employed for the production of maize, potatoes and other agricultural products. By this I mean that the leaf was grown in rows 20 inches apart, and was horse-hoed. Since attention was not then given to quality, the production was used mainly as a preparation for sheep dip. For many years the belief was general that the improved quality of tobacco leaf could not. be grown in this country. We have found that that is not the case. Whenever any new industry is being established, the practice has been for governments to, as far as possible, give it every assistance by means of bounties or protection through the customs; and it is a fact that many industries which have been assisted in this way have not had a total capital investment that would he represented in the value of one tobacco farm. But, having been promised high, if not prohibitive, duties, to say nothing of the exchange advantage, they were able to make a start, and some have become fairly well established. I mention these artificial forms of assistance because I am sure that some, at least, of these new industries, will, when normal times return, go to the wall. Doubtless, the same fate also awaits those tobacco-growers who have not given sufficient attention to the quality of leaf, the climatic conditions and the most improved methods of cultivation. We must not lose sight of the fact that climatic and soil conditions, as well as a number of other important factors, have to be considered if we expect to produce high quality tobacco leaf in this country. Already quite a number of people are growing good tobacco. Unfortunately, quite a number of people are also growing a leaf that is unsuitable for any purpose other than that to which Australian-grown tobacco was applied many years ago, namely, as a mixture for sheep dip.

The difficulties confronting our tobacco growers to-day had their parallel in the troubles that beset our wheat and wool-growers in the initial stages of their industry. For very many years wheat production in Australia was on an uneconomical basis. Our wheat-farmers did not then appreciate or understand the value of modern practice, nor werethey well advised as to the varieties ofwheat to be grown. Consequently, there were frequent heavy losses in all States, due to smut, rust, take-all, and a number of other plant diseases. Happily those difficulties have been practically overcome, but I remind the committee that success came only when our farmers realized the importance of modern agricultural practice, and the need for cultivating the best varieties of wheat. I venture the opinion that success will come to our tobacco-growing industry through the same avenue, and, I hope, in the near future. It is not too much to expect that, as the result of valuable research workdone by Commonwealth and State experts, blue mould and spotted leaf, which now take heavy toll of the industry, will eventually be eliminated, and that, by the application of proved methods of cultivation, in suitable soils, we shall be able to produce amuch larger proportion of high grade leaf than is being done now. But it is almost certain that, while the industry is in its initial stages, many men who are producing dark leaf tobacco on unsuitable soils will drop out. It may not be widely known that, by many farmers, tobacco-growing is regarded as a side-line, to enable them to carry on in this most difficult time of depression. For the most part these growers are mixed farmers, who are cultivating only a small area as an experiment, and in the circumstances they could hardly hope to be successful. So we may naturally expect that growers who are not devoting the whole of their time to the industry will, in due course, drop out, leaving only the efficient growers in the business.

It seems to me that the success of the industry depends on the production of a high quality leaf. I understand that there are twelve qualities, namely, lemon, grades 1, 2 and 3; bright mahogany, grades 1 and 2 ; mahogany, grades 1, 2 and 3; and dark leaf, grades 1, 2, 3 and 4. The honorable member for Kennedy (Mr. Riordan), when complaining of the refusal of the manufacturers to purchase the crops of some growers, which, the latter declared, consisted of sound, marketable leaf, asked who should be thejudge when there was a difference of opinion between buyer and seller. I takeit that the values of the respective grades are determined in much the same way that the value of wool was appraised during the war period, and I assume that only an expert can distinguish between the different grades. I understand that the demand is for lemon leaf, grades 1, 2 and 3, and for bright mahogany, grades 1 and 2, and that last year the buyers took approximately 10,000,000 lb. of the Australian crop. 1 was also pleased to hear the Minister state to-day that the manufacturers had agreed to purchase 6,000,000 lb. of this year's crop. As it is estimated that the total production will be only about 6,000,000 lb., the buyers have, apparently, undertaken to purchase the whole of this year's Australian production. But I noted that the Minister stated definitely it was the intention of the manufacturers to purchase only the three grades of lemon leaf and No. 1 grade of bright mahogany. If this is correct, it would appear that No. 2 grade of bright mahogany, the three grades of mahogany, and the four grades of dark leaf, will not be purchased this year, except for the replacement of an unknown quantity of dark tobacco that was used. As the grades which the manufacturers intend to buy this year will represent not more than 40 per cent. of the total crop, it would appear, if the Minister's statement is correct that this year's crop will be only 6,000,000 lb., that the manufacturers will not buy more than 40 per cent. of it.

I think I am right in saying that the arrangement made last year for the purchase of the crop was satisfactory to the majority of growers. At all events, it gave satisfaction to those who produced a decent quality of leaf. Apparently, therefore, those growers whose crop is not suited to the requirements of Australian smokers must do what other producers are required to do with their waste crop - scrap the unsaleable portion of it. I imagine that many growers, especially those who are endeavouring to produce tobacco by irrigation methods, and are not turning out the lighter grades which are in demand, will be obliged to face this problem immediately.

As this subject was thoroughly thrashed out when last it was before the committee, much of what has been said in this debate will, I feel sure, be repeated when we are discussing the excise duties. I should like to see a margin between the excise duty on tobacco manufactured from the Australian leaf and tobacco manufactured from the imported leaf. There was, a margin previously, but with the import duty at 3s. per lb., that margin has practically disappeared; with the result, I am told, that sales of Australian tobacco have fallen off by approximately 40 per cent. I feel sure that, if we could establish a margin between the tobacco manufactured from the Australian leaf and that made from the imported leaf, we should create a greater demand for Australian tobacco.

I do not admit that Australian tobacco is inferior to the imported article, and I was interested in a statement made last night by the honorable member for Bendigo (Mr. E.F. Harrison) who read brief extracts from reports by three experts who expressed the view that Australian tobacco was uniformly of a high standard. That is my view also. When I visited the Mother Country recently, I found it impossible to purchase there a tobacco that was quite suited to my taste. I understand that other Australians have had a similar experience. Consequently most Australians who are about to visit Great Britain take with them a sufficient quantity of the Australian tobacco to last them while they are abroad. I have no doubt also, that people who visit this country from Great Britain or America, for the same reason bring with them supplies of British or American tobacco. This difficulty, if it can be called a difficulty, is due to the fact that tobacco is an acquired taste. It seems to me that if we had a variation of, say, 6d. in the price of 2-oz. packets of Australian and foreign tobaccoes, most people would purchase the Australian product, and acquire a taste for it. I, therefore, hope that, when we are discussing the excise duties, the Government will realize the importance of doing something in this direction, and that the Minister will bring down a proposal to alter the excise rates 6d. up and 6d. down. I am indifferent as to the precise form the amendment should take so long as it is calculated to encourage the local industry, and give a margin of1s. in excise. Not long ago, when the Government altered the duty to permit the introduction of Fijian bananas, an arrangement was made to assist the Queensland banana industry to the extent of £5,000, the amount which it was estimated the duty on imported bananas would realize. If now the Government will make the small variation which I have suggested in the excise duty on tobacco, it will not affect the revenue in the slightest degree, but will assist the Australian industry very materially. I think every honorable member is anxious to maintain the revenue from the tobacco duties, and, at the same time, assist the local grower. This, I repeat, can be done by the suggested differentiation between the duties to encourage our growers to produce more largely of those grades that are in demand.

Mr. A.GREEN (Kalgoorlie) [4.58].- I agree with the honorable member for Corangamite (Mr. Gibson) that if we are to ensure the expansion of the Australian tobacco-growing industry, it will be necessary to ensure a difference between the market prices for Australian and imported tobaccos. But I cannot agree with his suggested alteration of the excise duty. The amendment moved by the honorable member for Kennedy (Mr. Riordan) is, I believe, the only solution of the problem. It is stated, in the circular which has. been issued to all honorable members, that the net result of the last alteration of the tobacco duties was to ease the position for importers, and to increase the duty on Australian tobacco from 2s. 4d. per lb. to 4s. 6d. per lb. - an in crease of 94 per cent. That, in my opinion, was a great mistake. As well as establishing our own secondary industries, we must do everything we can to put our primary industries on a prosperous footing.If the wheat-growers, tobacco-planters, and wool-growers continue to receive prices on which they cannot show a profit, the country, despite all its secondary industries, must become bankrupt. That being so, and seeing that the wheat-growing and other long established industries are not at present paying their way, we should welcome any effort to ensure that the consumption of tobacco in Australia shall be confined as much as possible to Australian-grown leaf. For too long has Australia been an open market for the products of' the United States of America. For every £1 worth of goods . we sell to that country we buy £7 or £8 worth from there. I have no prejudice against Americans as such. I have lived among them, and know them to be smart business people; but we should cultivate the same spirit towards our industries as they have done towards theirs. As the honorable member for Kennedy (Mr. Riordan) pointed out, there would be very little chance of finding a. sale for Australian tobacco in Virginia. We cannot, perhaps, prohibit the importation of American leaf immediately; but we could produce 16,000,000 lb. of the' 23,000,000 lb. consumed annually in Australia, and import for blending purposes the other 7,000,000 lb. to suit the palate of those who cannot be satisfied with anything but American leaf. Taste in tobacco is largely a matter of custom. At one time I occupied a position in a branch of the Customs Department, and while there met a man who insisted on importing Mexican cigars. No ordinary Cuban cigars would do him; only Mexican tobacco was, in his opinion, a satisfactory and desirable smoke. In the same way, many sea captains who have traded in the East Indies for years believe that the only cigar worth smoking is the Burmese cheroot, which is made of dark tobacco. These cheroots can be bought for about id. each' in Burma, and have a very fine flavour of their own.

It is necessary for us to develop all branches of primary production in Australia, and tobacco-growing provides an opportunity of employment for a great many persons. An important feature of the industry is that it is a large employer of labour. A young friend of mine, who recently began growing tobacco in the Ovens Valley, told me that, although he had been used to hard work, he had never previously encountered any job which made such demands on his dynamic energy as did tobacco-growing. Unfortunately, a man, after spending his days and a good part of his nights tending his crop, sometimes loses the whole of it. Tobacco-raising is even more risky than wheat-growing. Tobacco has many natural pests and diseases, and is quickly affected by climatic changes. In the Ovens Valley this year more than half the crop has been swept away by frost. The estimated crop was 4,500,000 lb., and of this 2,500,000 lb. has been lost overnight. Because of this everpresent danger of loss, growers find it necessary to plant a greater acreage than would otherwise be required. Last year. 12,000,000 lb. of Australian tobacco was sold, but over and above that, a considerable quantity was grown which was never marketed, because it had been damaged by blue mould and other pests. It is reasonable to assume that approximately the same acreage has been planted this year as last, yet it is estimated that this year's crop will bc only about 6,000,000 lb.

I have studied the Tariff Board's report on tobacco, and it seems to me that it has recommended reduced protection, first, because it fears that high duties may encourage a rush of inexperienced growers from other primary industries, and, secondly, because the cessation, of imports may lead to a loss of about £2,000,000 in revenue. 'In the course of its report, the board states -

Assuming the total requirements of leaf in Australia to be 20,000,000 lb. annually, and that there would still be approximately 4,000,000 lb. imported for blending purposes, particularly for cigarettes, this would leave a demand for 10,000,000 lb. of Australian leaf annually. Based on a yield of 800 lb. " per acre, it would require 20,000 acres of land to produce the 10,000,000 lb. annually. It will thus be seen that the demand is not very extensive. The loss of revenue previously collected on 10,000,000 lb. of leaf imported under the duty of 3s. per lb. would be approximately £2,000,000.

If Australia can provide a market for 16,000,000 lb. of locally-grown leaf, let us produce that quantity, and let us make up the £2,000,000 in revenue from excise duty. It is a remarkable argument that production should be restricted so that we might swell our revenue by the duty paid on imported goods.

I was pleased to hear the honorable member for Henty (Sir Henry Gullett) speak this afternoon in that clear incisive fashion with which we are familiar, but he looked at this matter entirely from his own point of view. He seemed to take a great deal of credit to himself for the altered position . of the tobacco-growing industry as a result of the reduction of duties which he proposed. The fact that the import duty has been reduced from 5s. 2d. to 3s. per lb., and. that the excise duty on manufactured tobacco is the same for imported as for Australian leaf, renders it practically impossible for the manufacturers of Australian leaf to put the finished article on the market at a price which will attract the public. Australians have for so long been used to smoking American tobacco, that the only chance of inducing them to turn over to the local tobacco is to put the latter on the market at prices which will attract them. If imported and Australian tobaccoes are sold at the same price, the unthinking portion of the community will continue to smoke the tobacco to which they have become accustomed.

The Government has not taken adequate precautions to safeguard the growers' interests in regard to the disposal of the present crop. The honorable member for New England (Mr. Thompson) said that there was a general belief that the manufacturers proposed to buy only bright mahogany and better grades, which constitute only about 40 per cent, of the crop. To say that the manufacturers are prepared to take 6,000,000 lb. of tobacco-
Mr.Thompson. - The Minister has since corrected that, and said that the manufacturers have not stipulated any definite quantity.

Mr. A.GREEN. - In reality, no arrangement has been entered into with the manufacturers for the purchase of the present crop. The Government holds the key to the position, and it would be nothing short of criminal to ratify these duties until an undertaking has been obtained from the manufacturers for the purchase of the present crop at a fair price - 2s. 3d. per lb. if necessary.

There has been some irrelevant comment about Chinese being employed in the tobacco-growing industry. The fact that a handful of Chinese are engaged in growing tobacco does not weigh with me in the least. Only a remnant of the original Chinese growers now remain, and they have . been in the industry since the pioneering days. Surely they can be left to work out their declining years- without honorable members of -this. House trying to raise a racial issue on their account. In any case this does not concern the real issue.

I trust that the amendment of the honorable member for Kennedy (Mr. Riordan) will be carried, because his proposal represents the only way of securing a satisfactory price for the growers. We all desire to see the industry established in Australia. In Western Australia, in the electorate of the honorable member for Forrest (Mr. Prowse), some very fine tobacco is being grown, which is hardly second in quality even to that being produced at Mareeba. I believe that, with greater care and experience, Australia will be able to produce leaf equal to that at present being imported from abroad.

Mr. E.J. HARRISON (Wentworth) [5.15]. - I am glad to know that the Government intends to take a vote on this matter to-day. The Government has been particularly fair in dealing with the representations made from time to time on behalf of this industry. The consideration of the duties was postponed to enable additional facts to be presented, and a report has now been made which shows conclusively that, in reality, there were no new facts of any importance to be investigated. Certain honorable members endeavoured to strengthen the claims of the industry by saying that a deputation wished to place still further facts before the Minister. I have no doubt that the deputation has been heard, and, possibly, the case presented by it will have some influence on the judgment of. the committee. A number of peculiar arguments have been used to-day by honorable members opposite. Throughout the tariff discussions, it has been contended that members who support the Government take an unreasonable view of tariff matters in favouring the reduction of duties, and wish to destroy Australian industries by encouraging the use of goods manufactured in black-labour countries. Yet it now appears that the ridiculously high duties imposed by the Scullin Government have resulted in the employment of yellow labour in Australia.
Mr.Forde- The Chinese, to whom reference has been made, have been engaged in the tobacco industry in this country for 30 years.

Mr. E.J. HARRISON- Members on this side believe in the White Australia policy; but honorable members opposite ask for duties that will benefit yellow labour in this country. The position is Gilbertian. These Chinese are being exploited to the utmost in connexion with share-farming operations, particularly in the Tamworth district, and have had to pay absurdly high rentals for land that is said to be suitable for the cultivation of tobacco. "
Mr.Gander. - If they were Japanese, the honorable member would stand up for them.

Mr. E.J. HARRISON.- I still believe in the White Australia policy, and in the encouragement of Australian industries; but it seems to me, after weighing the facts impartially, that the action of the last Government, in encouraging extraordinarily high import duties on tobacco, caused an unhealthy boom in the value of tobacco lands, and gave encouragement to the production of leaf on unscientific linos and coloured labour. The conditions following this boom in tobacco lands approximate those resulting from the sugar-lands scandal in Queensland. Honorable members opposite are associated with' a party that excluded the kanakas from Queensland on the ground that they were taking the place of white men- Yet the honorable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr. A. Green) has declared to-day that he takes no notice of the Chinese who are now engaged in the tobacc'o industry in Australia. That the arguments of honorable members opposite are illogical is obvious.

The report of the tobacco expert appointed by this Government shows that the unsold leaf was not of sufficiently good quality to justify its manufacture for use by Australian smokers, and the honorable member for New England (Mr. Thompson) has told us that it was impossible for that officer to form a definite opinion on that matter. I refer honorable members to the report of the Australian Tobacco Investigation Committee, a semi-government body, appointed, I understand, in the first place, by the British-Australasian Tobacco Company, and eventually taken over by the Commonwealth Government. Referring to the results of- analyses of tobacco samples taken in all the States during the period from 1927-28 to 1929-30, the report of that committee showed that about 5 per cent, of the leaf examined was good cigarette leaf, 1$ per cent, fair cigarette, 15 per cent, good medium pipe, 22-J per cent, fair medium pipe, 17^ per cent, good heavy pipe, and 37-J per cent, poor, heavy, pipe tobacco. We are told by the Minister that the best tobacco grown in the Tamworth district was purchased, and that the residue, which consisted of about 90 per cent, of the total output, was unsuitable for manufacture. The honorable member for New England said that a chart compiled by the British-Australasian Tobacco Company was used by the expert, and insinuated that this company was not acting in the best interests of the growers; but I point out that this company, by its action, has endeavoured to improve the position of the Australian grower. Had it accepted low grade leaf indiscriminately, it . would have " destroyed the industry; but, by manufacturing only the best grades of leaf, it has encouraged the use of Australian tobacco of high quality. In the end, this will prove to be the best way to encourage an industry, which, in my opinion, has a bright future. It is a good revenue-producer, and the Government is preventing it from being ruined by. development on unsound lines. The Government's action will check the unhealthy boom in land values. When saturation point has been reached in the local production of tobacco leaf, those who have paid from £30 to £50 an acre for tobacco land will be sadder but wiser men. Only leaf of the best quality will be marketable, and those growers whose land enables them to produce only inferior leaf will be in the same position as those city manufacturers who have invested in businesses that are entirely uneconomic. I commend the Government for the action that it has taken in this matter.

Mr.GEORGE LAWSON (Brisbane) [5.25]. - The matter before the committee is of great importance to Australia as a whole, and it affects one of the great industries of Queensland, which probably produces the best tobacco that is grown in Australia. I hope that the Government will take heed of the amendment submitted by the honorable member for Kennedy (Mr. Riordan), and that a compromise will be reached, in order to allow the industry to be conducted on profitable lines. In my opinion, the tobacco-growers have not received sufficient consideration from this Government. Many of them have spent large sums of money in purchasing land suitable for tobacco culture. In Queensland, some thousands of men have invested their life's savings in acquiring tobacco properties, and, unless the protection afforded to them approximates that given by the Scullin Government, many of them will be thrown out of employment, and faced with financial ruin. The position in Queensland is not different from that in the other States. I am afraid that the Government does not fully realize the value of this industry to the Commonwealth. About 7,000 growers and their families are directly or indirectly engaged in the industry, and about 15,000 employees find work on the fields and in the tobacco factories. The value of the Australian crop in 1929-30 was £92,000, and in each of the two following years it was approximately £1,250,000. This indicates that the industry is deserving of all the protection that the present or any other government can give it. Had it not been for the duties imposed by the Scullin Administration, the big sums paid to the growers in 1930-31 and 1931-32 would have been sent overseas for the purchase of leaf grown in the United States of America, and elsewhere. The protection afforded by the Scullin Government resulted in the establishment of two new factories in Brisbane". These employ a large number of persons, and manufacture tobacco equal in quality to any produced in the Commonwealth. The honorable member for Kennedy quoted from some correspondence which he had received from an agent in New South Wales, in which it was stated that the Royal Agricultural Society of New South Wales had endeavoured to boycott tobacco manufactured solely from Queensland-grown leaf. I join with the honorable member in expressing resentment at the action of that society, which ought to do all it can to assist Australian primary production. I hops that the amendment moved by the honorable member for Kennedy will be accepted by the Minister, for, in that case, the industry will again be placed on a sound footing, and those engaged in it will be encouraged to continue their operations. I regret that the Minister has not seen his way clear to assure the committee that the" agreement entered into by his predecessor for the purchase of the Australian tobacco crop will be renewed this year. Because of that agreement, a considerable quantity of tobacco leaf was purchased from Australian growers, particularly those in Queensland, at reasonable rates last year. Should the agreement not be renewed this year, I fear that much of the Queensland crop will be left on the growers' hands; and if that happens, they will be ruined. If the Government cannot accept, the duties imposed by the Scullin Administration I 'trust that it will fix the. import duty at 4s. 6d. per lb. and the excise duty at 3s. per lb.

Mr. HUNTER(Maranoa) [5.34].- - This discussion could have ended last night had the Minister been willing to tell the committee of the Government's intentions in regard to the excise duty* on tobacco. With that information before them, honorable members could either have accepted or rejected the proposal for a duty of 3s. per lb. on imported tobacco leaf. Those who urge the reduction of duties generally do so on the ground that it will mean a lowering of the price to the consumer; but in the case of tobacco that has not been the result. There is no difference between the price charged for imported tobacco to-day and that at which it was sold when the duty on imported leaf was 5s. 2d. per lh. Although the duty has been reduced by 2s. 2d. per lb., the price qf tobacco made from imported leaf is the same as formerly. The reduction of the duty has had a harmful effect on the smokers of Australian-grown tobacco, because it caused the excise duty to be increased from 2s. 4d. to 4s. 6d. per lb. The net result of the Government's ' action has been to increase the prices of tobacco made from locally-grown leaf. Had the margin between the prices charged for tobacco made from imported leaf and tobacco made from Australian-grown leaf varied according to the reduction of the import. duty ou tobacco, it could be said that the lower duties had done the grower and consumer no harm, but that margin has not been maintained, for the price of locally-produced tobacco is almost' equal to that of tobacco made from importedleaf. It is not permissible to raise the duty on imported tobacco, and, therefore, I urge a reduction of the excise duty on locally-grown tobacco in order that a cheaper product may be placed on the market. If local tobacco were cheaper, more of it would be consumed, and less of the imported, and in that way the Australian industry would be assisted. Over and over again it has been stated that the growers of tobacco seek only a bounty. They have not obtained the advantage of any bounty; those who have benefited are the smokers of locally-produced tobacco. Foreign tobacco leaf can be landed in Australia at 4s. per lb., including duty, exchange and primage. The local industry did not take advantage of the charges imposed on imported leaf. Tobacco is the only article produced in Australia under the protection of our tariff in connexion with which full advantage has not been taken of the protection afforded to it. The price of locallyproduced tobacco has always been considerably lower than the landed cost of imported tobacco. Any advantage received by the local industry has been passed on to the consumers of tobacco, with the result that there has been a greatly increased consumption of Australian-grown tobacco. That "Havelock" tobacco and other well-known brands of tobacco are no longer labelled " Pure Virginian" proves that in their manufacture Australian leaf is now employed. And since the manufacturers of those brands of tobacco have not reduced their prices, it is obvious that they are taking advantage of their position. No one contends that unsaleable tobacco leaf should be bought by the manufacturing companies. If an unsatisfactory product is left on the growers' hands, the manufacturing companies are not to blame. I ask only that an opportunity be given to the manufacturers of tobacco from Australian-grown leaf -to place on the market a cheap tobacco, in order that smokers may be led to acquire a taste for Australian brands of tobacco, and in that way develop this Australian industry.

If the Government will announce its intention in regard to the excise duty on tobacco, a great deal of time will even yet be saved; otherwise, most of the arguments which have been advanced in connexion with the import duty on tobacco will be repeated when the excise duty comes before the committee.

Mr. SCHOLFIELD(Wannon) [5.45].- This item has been thoroughly traversed, and it is high time that a vote was taken on it. The subject was also debated exhaustively when the duty was reduced from 5s. 2d. to 3s., and on that occasion a majority of honorable members favoured the reduction. Probably honorable members were influenced by the knowledge that the Australian tobacco industry was then receiving a foolishly' high protection - a fact that was admitted by at least one grower. When this Government assumed office, it was faced with an adverse financial position, and among other things it discovered that the amount of revenue raised from imposts on tobacco did not reach £6,500,000, as had been expected. Consequently, it reduced the duty on imported tobacco to 3s., on the assumption that that would bring about greater importation, which would yield the desired revenue of £6,500,000. The Government's anticipation was realized. It is generally admitted that tobacco is a legitimate object of taxation. Incidentally, the manufacturers paid the fixed average price of 2s. 3d. per lb. on something like 10,500,000 lb., instead of the 7,200,000 lb. which they originally undertook to purchase, and I suggest % that their heavier purchase account for the revenue exceeding the Government's estimate. Because of the reduced production of Australian tobacco this year, and the resultant diminution in excise collections, the revenue ' derived by the Government from the industry will be less than it was last year, and the Government would find itself in difficulties if it did not take steps to correct the position.

I was sorry to hear the honorable member for New England (Mr. Thompson) condemn the action of a responsible officer of the department: If the Government cannot depend upon its experts to supply unbiased reports, to whom is.it to turn ? Surely not to the statements of the honorable member for New England ! We should support the departmental officers, who are doing a great service to Australia, and are quite impartial.

I firmly believe that, had the duties on tobacco not been reduced, the tobacco industry in Australia would have fallen into a chaotic condition. In a year it' increased its production from 2,000,000 lb. to approximately 13,500,000 lb. As our requirements of Australian tobacco are between 16,000,000 and 17,000,000 lb., it can easily be seen that, had the increase continued, our market would have been glutted with the local leaf, and as most of our industries appeal to the Government so soon as they find themselves in trouble, there is no doubt that the Government would have had to listen to a woeful story from the tobacco growers. I believe that the action of .the Government has been most beneficial to the industry, for it has eliminated | many who were producing from land which was quite unsuited for the purpose, together with others who rushed into the industry without any previous knowledge of it, grew an unsuitable variety of leaf, and marketed that leaf in anything but a proper manner. Since the protection sanctioned by the Parliament gave a stimulus to the industry, land for tobacco-growing has increased in price enormously. Some months ago I accompanied a grower on a journey through some Victorian tobacco country, and, as we passed an area of land that appeared to be of a heavy, clayey nature, I asked him what it would be worth, and was told, " Between £30 and £40 an acre." I also asked what the land had been used for previously, and my companion said, "For dairying." If people go out of dairying into tobacco-growing, it indicates that they know nothing about the latter industry. The action of the Government put a stop to that sort of thing.
The honorable member for Herbert (Mr. Martens) said that there is no land south of Mareeba suitable for the growing of tobacco.
Mr. Martens.- I did not. I said that that statement . was made by Mr. Tregenna the New .South Wales tobacco expert.

Mr. SCHOLFIELD.- I deny its truth, for there is quite a lot of land south of Mareeba that is suitable for tobacco growing, and, in saying that, I do not wish to boost the industry, for I realize the danger of allowing it to carry on quite uncontrolled, enjoying a high protection.

I was pleased to hear the Minister's remarks regarding excise, and I shall await with interest his further statement on the subject next week. We must do everything possible to induce smokers to use local tobacco. Previously, we were discouraging its use by permitting the production and manufacture of tobacco that did not suit the palate of most smokers. Obviously, if each pipe smoker decreased his consumption of tobacco by 50 per cent., definite injury would be done to the Australian industry. The Government examined all of these matters, and its _ action has been of immense service to our growers.

Mr.WHiTE (Balaclava- Minister for Trade and Customs) [5.55]. - I have received the deputation that was mentioned yesterday as being en route to Canberra, and I have listened caref ully to the debate, which has revealed nothing that is new, except a suggestion by certain honorable members that there should be a reduction of the excise duty on Australian tobacco. Mr. WHITE.-No. The item has been postponed since the 28th March last, so that honorable members and others concerned have had ample time to bring forward any new proposals relating to it. It is apparent that, when submitting a case for the reduction of the excise duty on local leaf, honorable members must take into consideration importations over a number of years, if they desire to be fair to the industry. It is illogical to assume that because the importations of tobacco were high, say, last year, they will continue to be so in subsequent years. Those who support a reduction of excise also desire the displacement of imported leaf by the local article. Does it not follow that the greater the quantity of imported leaf that is displaced, the higher the excise duty on local leaf will have to be. The honorable member for Forrest (Mr. Prowse) pointed that out, but, unfortunately, he did not make himself very clear. The matter of excise must be left for separate consideration, when the excise schedule is introduced next week. I am glad that the honorable member for Forrest now agrees that a protection of 3s. per lb., amounting to approximately 300 per cent., in favour of the Australian industry is adequate.

The only other matter which calls for comment is the reply of the honorable member for New England (Mr. Thompson). I was glad that the honorable member for Wannon (Mr. Scholfield) took the honorable member to task for attacking the Government official who made an inquiry into the industry. That inquiry was held because complaint was made by the honorable member for NewEngland that tobacco-growers in his district were being victimized. As a matter of fact, the debate was adjourned la3t March principally to enable the inquiry to be made, and the official concerned submitted a quite impartial report, well written, and accurate in detail.
Mr. Martens.- The report was made by an honest man.
Mr. WHITE.-The honorable member for Herbert (Mr. Martens) paid a high tribute to the official. The examination was not a cursory one, but covered the Tamworth, Manila, Gunnedah, Boggabri,
Somerton, Scone, and Quirindi districts. Tn his report, Mr. Marks stated -
I have endeavoured to give a true and unbiased view of the position, and where any doubt existed, I have given the grower the benefit of the doubt.
How dare the honorable member for New England challenge an opinion of an expert given under such conditions, and claim that his words were inspired by the tobacco companies. Later, Mr. Marks writes -
While on my tour, I inspected 05 per cent, of the growers with unsold leaf.

If the honorable member for New England was eager that the inspection made by Mr. Marks should be facilitated, why did he not make the task of that official easier? Mr. Marks says that though he interviewed 95 per cent, of the growers who had unsold leaf, he did not receive much co-operation. That officer had no axe to grind, and he viewed the matter impartially. I contend that, having declared that all of the unpurchased tobacco in those districts was usable, the honorable member for New England was in a desperate position when this report was submitted showing that his contentions were groundless. The honorable member should have been a good loser and admitted that he was wrong.
Mr. Thompson.- I have not yet lost, as the honorable gentleman will discover.

Mr. WHITE.-In the districts I have mentioned 10,371 bales of tobacco were offered for sale, and the manufacturers purchased 5,565 bales, 4,826 being rejected. As I said last night, with no disparagement to the industrious Chinese, 52.28 per cent, of the rejected crop was produced by Chinese labour, the Chinese either growing for themselves, or on a 3hare-farming basis with Europeans. "The majority of these growers had been out of the industry for years, but were attracted back to it because of the glowing reports made by persons such as the honorable member for New England. They persisted in growing tobacco of the old dark type, although, for a number of years, they have been advised that that class of leaf is entirely unsuitable for manufacturing requirements.

As a matter of fact, it appears as though the honorable member is a danger to the growers. The report of the senior agronomist is unbiased and impartial, and his opinion should be sufficiently reliable for us to accept it.

I have already made the statement that for this season the biggest tobacco company will buy all the yellow leaf that is available, and also the quantity of mahogany and dark leaf that it usually buys.
Mr. GIBSON- At what price?

Mr. WHITE.- The company has not announced the price, and we cannot get it to do so. At first it would make no arrangement at all for this year. It was only after a great deal of time had been spent in negotiations that the conditions that I have referred to were agreed upon.
Mr. Hill.- That statement is enough to justify us in voting for higher duties.

Mr. WHITE.-The honorable member for Echuca (Mr. Hill) is one of those who are constantly objecting to duties on secondary products, but, like the honorable member for Forrest, who is an agricultural1 protectionist advocate of the highest possible duties on primary products. I ask the honorable member to realize that the tobacco industry is already being protected to the extent of about 300 per cent. against tobacco produced by white labour in Canada.

I appeal to honorable members to consider this duty apart from the excise duty. The excise duties will be considered next week, when the excise schedule is before the committee. The import duty which the Government is proposing is adequate. It will enable the growers to sell this year all their high-class leaf, which is usually about 30 per cent. of the crop.
Mr. Forde.-What about the mahogany leaf?

Mr.WHITE. - The proportion of that quality that is used annually will be bought this year.We must remember that last year one company bought two years' supply for maturation purposes. It, therefore, will not be able to buy so much this year. Unfortunately, in consequence of frosts and pests, the crop will be smaller this year. If honorable members will consider the facts, they will realize that the Government is protecting the revenue and also the producers of good-quality tobacco leaf. Its policy, therefore, will be in the best interests of both the growers and the consumers.

Mr. NAIRN(Perth) [8.0].- The proposals before the committee are for duties of 2s. British and 4s. general on sheet glass, and deferred duties on and after the 1st June, 1933, of 40 per cent. and 60 per cent. respectively. I support these proposals, subject to any recommendation the Tariff Board may make after further investigation. The project for the manufacture of sheet glass in Australia was first launched in 1925. The duties at that time were 2s. and 4s., with deferred duties of 45 per cent, and 60 per cent., to become operative when the industry was sufficiently established to he able to supply a reasonable share of local requirements. Encouraged by this protection, the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited commenced the manufacture of sheet glass, and claims to have invested £300,000 in the enterprise. The ad valorem duties were further deferred from time to time, and were due for revision again in August of 1930. But in June of that year the Scullin Government, which had recently assumed office, put the deferred duties into operation without consulting the Tariff Board. The immediate result was an increase in the price of this glass. The Australian company was not able to produce a single sheet of glass for sale. Large stocks had been accumulated by importers, and upon these enormous profits were made.
Mr. Watkins.- By the importers?

Mr. NAIRN.- Yes ; but they included the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited. With almost uncanny prescience of the Government's intentions, the importers had accumulated enormous stocks of glass just prior to the deferred duties becoming operative, and they were able to charge whatever prices they chose. The cost to the public was enormous. The Tariff Board had calculated, apparently for a normal building year, that the added cost of the deferred duties would be about £150,000. That affords some idea of the magnificent bonus that was presented to those who had imported glass in anticipation of the operation of the deferred duties. The Australian company was quite unable to supply the market, hut for about two years it succeeded in stalling off the public by means which may be' fairly described as tricky and discreditable. In proof of that statement, I quote some of the examples given in evidence before the Tariff Board. An Adelaide firm placed an order with the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited in July, 1931. The manufacturers temporized in various ways, and did not deliver the goods until May, 1932. The quality of the glass when delivered was inferior, and unsuitable for the market. A later consignment received by the same firm was described as 'being of not better quality than the first. Another firm produced its correspondence to the board to show that for ten months it had been fooled by prevaricating statements issued by the manufacturer. A third witness gave evidence that delivery of its order had been delayed for nine months, at the end of which he accepted other goods in substitution for those he had ordered. For two years the public suffered great inconvenience and heavy cost. When the present Government came into office the matter was again referred to the Tariff Board, which, in a report dated August, 1932, declared that the local manufacturer was not in a position to supply commercially, nor was it clear when production on a commercial scale could be expected. The company protested, as it is protesting to-day, that the board's report was out of date, that since the inquiry had been held, the conditions had altered, and that if effect were given to the board's recommendations, manufacture would have to be discontinued, and many workers would be thrown out of employment. As a result of these representations the' Government imposed an embargo on imports and instituted a system of rationing pending a further investigation by the board. That inquiry was held at the end of November, 1932, and related to the quality, quantity and price of the Australian product. In regard to quality, there was a conflict of evidence. The company produced some customers and two architects who stated that the Australian product had improved and was substantially satisfactory. On the other hand, there was overwhelming testimony condemnatory of the product of the Australian company. Several customers from the country gave evidence of the shabby treatment to which they had been subjected by the company for many months, and Mr. L. E. Irwin, president of the Royal Victorian Institute of Architects, said that about 90 per cent, of the Australian product was unsatisfactory for building purposes, whereas the average rejection of Belgian glass was only about 10 per cent., whilst its f.o.b. cost was only one-third of the price charged for the local product. In its report, dated January of this year, the board found that there had been some improvement in the output of the Australian company, but that the proportion of defective glass was still unduly large. As to quality, the board concluded -
Although there has been an improvement in the average quality, there have been considerable fluctuations and variations of the quality marketed, o

The average quality of the glass produced up to the temporary closing down of the factory is far below the quality of glass imported into Australia in recent years, and is not such as to fill the demands of the building trade.
As to the ability of the local factory to supply orders, the board came to the conclusion -
. . that the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited has failed to meet the requirements of the building trade in the supply of suitable plain sheet, glass.

In regard to cost, the board made a comparison between the Australian charges and the f.o.b. prices in Belgium and the United Kingdom. These show that for 16-oz. glass the f.o.b. price of Belgian thirds is 8s. 7d. per 100 square feet, and for British fourths, 12s. 1½d. whereas the price of Australian glass, which is inferior to the other two, is 27s. The board added -

At present, in spite of the added cost of importing due to exchange and primage, 10-oz. glass, first bracket, can be landed into store from the United Kingdom at 23s. 10id. per 100 square feet, including 3s. duty and 2{5J per cent, exchange, and from Belgium at 21s. 7d. per 100 square feet, including 4s. duty and approximately 75 per cent, exchange.

The board came to the conclusion that the Australian industry is not economic. The company is now claiming duties which would amount to prohibition. It has stated frankly that it will be unable to conduct its business satisfactorily unless it is given a complete monopoly of the Australian market. The board is of opinion that the granting of a monopoly is not justified, and could be made only at the cost of the public, and that, if the industry cannot carry on with the protection recommended, it should not be further encouraged.

The history of glass-making in Australia is one of inefficiency from the commencement. There is a big market in Australia for sheet glass, and the company has had the most liberal protection; throughout the greater part of the period of its operation there has been control of imports by the Minister for Trade and Customs. Had the local company been in a position at any time to supply the local market, it would., under the conditions operating, have had the whole market to itself ; but, notwithstanding the fact that it has been in existence since 1925, it has failed to supply the requirements of the Australian trade. I understand that deputations and counter deputations have waited upon the Minister, and that the plea that was put up two years ago is now being put up - that the conditions have altered since the time of the Tariff Board's inquiry, and that the company is now in a position to supply the local market. If the request of the company were acceded to, and it obtained a monopoly of the market of Australia, it is certain that, as a result, the people of Australia who are obliged to use glass would pay for it three times the price charged to the people of European manufacturing companies for similar glass. It is not fair to ask the people to pay such a considerable subsidy to any local industry. If the board's recommendation is accepted, the rates of duty will be 40 per cent. British, and 60 per cent, foreign, which, having regard to primage and exchange, ' is equivalent to 80 per cent* British and 100 per cent, foreign, plus freight and insurance. If the Australian industry is not able to carry on successfully under those conditions, it is not worth protecting. I support the proposals as set out in the schedule.

Mr. WHITE(Balaclava- Minister for Trade and Customs) [8.18].- This item of sheet glass is undoubtedly one of the most difficult in the whole tariff schedule. It is a legacy from the past, when we imagined that we could have a self sufficient, walled-in, domestic market, and that we could establish industries no matter how uneconomic they were, because we thought that the days of prosperity would always continue. The United States of America is the world's object Wesson in showing that a nation cannot be self-contained. With its enormous export trade, its immense resources, its wealth and investments, it thought that it had a monopoly of prosperity; but' that proved to be a fallacy. However much we may have supported high duties in the past, we are all beginning to realizenow that the flow of imports and exports must continue, and that customs duties must be only sufficient to enable a country's industries to exist protected from unfair competition from other countries. If a nation does not accept that view, and still persists in a policy of self -containment and economic nationalization, it invites retaliation. Australia has already had a taste of that; so has the United States of America. It has become more and more unpopular in the markets of the world, and is now paying for its folly. It has been proved that, no matter how high a tariff wall may be, it can be undermined and brought down by currency debasement, by one nation depreciating its currency so that its goods can enter a well-protected domestic market in another country.

In connexion with the sheet glass industry, deferred duties were imposed some years ago, and their history is this: Under the 1921-30 tariff duties of 2s. per 100 square feet British and 4s. general were payable on plain clear sheet glass. Provision for deferred duties of l1/2d. per lb. or 45 per cent. ad valorem, British, and 2d. per lb. or 60 per cent. ad valorem, general was incorporated in the tariff on the 2nd September, 1925, as the result of an application by the Australian Glass Manufacturers Company for protective duties, and the deferred rates were scheduled to operate on and from the 1st July, 1926. Their operation was postponed from time to time on the recommendation of the Tariff Board. The last postponement was until the 1st August, 1930, but the company advised the Customs Department in March of that year that its works would be ready for production in August, and requested that the deferred duties be brought into operation on the 1st April, 1930, so that stocks of imported glass would not accumulate to the extent of closing the market for the Australian product when it was released. The previous Government had tabled a schedule in June, 1930, which provided for duties equivalent to the deferred duties, although the works were not then ready for production. It was not until November, 1931, that the company first announced to the trade its intention to commence production. On this announcement, orders were placed with local manufacturers by merchants and users throughout Australia, but the company was incapable of satisfying those orders. That cannot be denied. Last year I quoted a letter which the local company addressed to a firm asking it to cancel an order because it was not in a position to fulfil it. Had it not been for the fact that the building trade was experiencing a lean time, the increased duties on glass would have seriously affected employment in that calling. The Tariff Board has, within the past few months, furnished two reports relating to the duties on plain clear sheet glass - one on the 19th August, 1932, and the other on the 26th January, 1933. It was on the first report that the present Government took action in September last to reduce the duties to the 1921-30tariff level. The principal reasons behind the board's recommendation of August, 1932, were -
(a) The local manufacturer was not in a position to produce commercially, nor was it clear when production on a commercial basis could be expected.
(b) The rates of duty were so high that they would seriously add to the cost in Australia of an important commodity without commensurate advantages to Australia.

The board stated that the high duties then obtaining would have meant an added cost to the community of over £150,000 per annum if the whole of the requirements were imported, and at that date glass had not been successfully manufactured in Australia. In view of the claims of local manufacturers that the position regarding local production had greatly improved since June - when the board held its first inquiries - the question was again referred to it on the 23rd September, 1932. The board was asked the following questions: -
1. The capacity of the applicant company to supply the Australian market with suitable glass in sufficient quantities ata reasonable price.
2. The rates of duty necessary for the protection of the industry, providing the industry is efficiently organized.

Concurrent with the reference of the question to the Tariff Board a proclamation was issued prohibiting the importation of plain clear sheet glass except with the consent of the Minister. I may mention that delivery has been allowed of all the glass on order at the time the prohibition was proclaimed. The deliveries aggregated some 4,000,000 square feet, and they were kept in bond while the prohibition operated.
Mr. FoRDE- When was the prohibition, with rationing, first applied?

Mr. WHITE.- It was first applied by the honorable member, when Minister, at the time the high duties were imposed, was continued, and is still in operation. The Tariff Board held its second inquiry in November, 1932, and furnished its report on the 26th January, 1933. In the opinion of the board the justification for protective duties depends upon the ability of the local manufacturer to supply the needs of the Australian market, and the board was of the opinion that these three aspects must be considered - quality, supply and price. I am sure that honorable members will agree that the consideration of these factors is essenti.il in determining whether any industry warrants protection. The board concluded that although there has been an improvement iti the average quality of glass produced, there have been considerable fluctuations and variations of the quality marketed. It was also remarked by tie board that the average quality of the glass produced up to the temporary closing down of the factory was far below the quality of glass imported into Australia in recent years, and. was not such as to fill the demands of the building trade. After examining the volume of evidence submitted at the inquiry, the board considered that the local manufacturer had failed to meet the requirements of the building trade in the supply of suitable plain clear sheet glass. The board pointed out that the local manufacturers'' selling prices of the four brackets commonly ordered in 16-oz. and 21-oz. weights exceeded the landed costs of imported glass, excluding duty, but including exchange, by - British (16-oz.), 4s. 6d. per case of 100 sq. ft; (21-oz.) 7s. 6d. per case of 100 sq. ft.; and Belgian (16-oz.), 9s. per cass of 100 sq. ft.; (21-oz.) 13s. 6d. per case of 100 sq. ft. With regard to the local company's contention that, by doing the bulk of distributing itself, the cost to the public would be lowered, and that the high rates imposed by the Scullin Government would not affect the prices to the user, the board stated that, taking all factors into consideration, it was convinced that distributing costs would be increased, rather than decreased, by adding seriously to the first cost, of glass to the distributing trade. The board concluded that the current sailing-prices of Australian plain clear sheet glass would mean increased costs to users.

Taking into consideration the nature of the industry, the limited Australian market, the difficulty of disposing of the large proportion of lower-grade glass, and the costs of production, as supplied by the company, the board conclude.? that satisfactory glass can be produced in Australia only at a cost that will detrimentally affect the building industry, and will thus tend to decrease employment. I think that it is admitted by the company itself that a great deal of its product is not of high quality and that much of it is so inferior that it has to go back into the furnaces.
Mr. Riley.- Not a higher percentage than in oversea factories.

Mr. WHITE-The oversea factories have a sale for inferior grades of glass. They can be disposed of in South America or in the East, whereas in Australia a fairly high grade is required by the building trade. In short, the board is of opinion that the industry is an uneconomic one, which can be supported only at a cost too groat to a dependent industry, such as the building trade.
Mr. Hutchin.- Why protect it at all?

Mr. WHITE.- This is a legacy of the past.. The company started operations because of the deferred duties. It has been in existence for several years and employs something like 240 men. Every aspect of the position must be considered.
The questions asked of the board by the Minister, and the replies furnished by it, are briefly as follow : -
Question 1. - The capacity of the applicant company to supply the Australian market with suitable glass in sufficient quantities at a reasonable price.
Reply. - The company has failed to satisfy the board of its present capabilities on all three points, namely, quality, quantity, and price.
QUESTION 2. - The rates of duty necessary for the protection of the industry, providing the industry is efficiently organized.

REPLY - The reply to question 1 clearly shows that the board is of opinion that the local industry is not efficiently organized at present. If the company can bridge the gap between present production costs and selling prices, the following rates would be necessary to secure the market to Australian manufacturers, based on their promised selling prices: - 100 per cent. British, 175 per cent, general.

If these duties were granted, most of the protection would have to be used in fixing the price of Australian glass, and the board was not prepared to recommend such high rates. The board recommends the present rates of 2s. per 100 sq. ft. British, and 4s. general, with provision for deferred duties of 45 per cent. British, and 75 per cent, general, such deferred duties to be either operated or terminated at the end of twelve months, according to whether it can or cannot be proved that such duties would be effective. 'The deferred rates now recommended are higher by 5 per cent. British, and 15 per cent, general, than those at present included in the schedule. If the deferred duty were applied, the ad valorem rate would be higher than previously. The board is of the opinion that, for the twelve months during which the deferred duty is held in suspense, importations should continue to be rationed under cover of the prohibition that now operates. Honorable members are aware that last year, when a large quantity of glass arrived in Australia, it was held in bond, and permits for its withdrawal were issued from time to time. The imports of glass into Australia within recent years have been as follow: - 1028-20.-10,000,000 sq. ft., valued at f 81, 000, of which the United Kingdom supplied 1,600,000 sq. ft., and Belgium 7.800,000 sq. ft. 1920-30.-19,000,000 sq. ft., valued at £152,000. 1930- 31.-1,949,000 lb., valued at £13.000. 1931- 32.-703,000 lb., valued at £4,000. 1932- 33. - 5,000,000 lb., which includes what was held in bond (8 months).
The glass held in bond had to be sold, because bond charges were mounting up, and the local company was unable to supply the orders that it received.
Mr. Forde.- What is the Minister's estimate of Australia's annual requirements ?
Mr. WHITE.- The board estimates that the present annual consumption in Australia is 5,000,000 sq. ft. ; and it considers that three-fourths of that quantity should be permitted to be imported.

The Government is prepared to accept the board's report if the facts are as stated by it. Since the board furnished its report in January last, however; the local manufacturers have represented that the position has changed considerably since the board took evidence and prepared its report. It is alleged that 240 persons may lose their employment if the recommendations of the board a£a adopted. The Government would be very sorry to see any person thrown out of work by reason of the operation of the tariff. Its tariff policy is calculated to assist both primary and secondary industries. The diminution of unemployment throughout Australia has shown that that policy is working satisfactorily. The Ottawa agreement also has been shown to be working successfully, making for greater economic 'unity, with resultant Empire prosperity, in which Australia is sharing. The Government does not always give credence to the threat that hundreds of men will be thrown out of work. It has heard those stories before, and knows that some vested interests will use the working lives of their employees more or less as industrial cannon fodder. The threat is held over the Government that if fiscally it takes this or that action, a number of men will lose their employment. It does not accept such statements without serious inquiry. In a certain notable instance, it was found that that was done merely for political purposes; the industry had not suffered in any way by reason of the operation of the tariff.
Mr. Riley.- To what industry does the Minister refer?
Mr. WHITE.-The honorable gentleman is well aware of the industry that I have in mind.
The CHAIRMAN. - Any reference to an industry that does not come under the item that is now before the Chair, would not be in order.

Mr. WHITE.-I merely mention that such threats have been made in the past. The manufacturers' conclusions in regard to quantity and quality have been seriously challenged. On the question of price, the company claims that, since manufacture commenced in Australia, the prices to the user, as distinct from the distributor, have been very considerably reduced. On the other hand, the importers, who also have been heard by way of deputation, contend that the board's recommendation for the continuation of the prohibition, and the rationing thereunder, is illogical, and is against the weight of the evidence and the conclusions to which the board has come. They point out - rightly, I think - that frequent changes have disorganized business to a very marked extent. It is but fair to say that the importers are prepared to accept the recommendation of the board, with the rationing suggested, although they question the feasibility of equitable rationing.

The Government is not prepared to accept ex parte statements from either side. It is willing to afford an opportunity to those who make statements to establish their accuracy. There is now in Australia a sufficient quantity of glass to supply the requirements for at least a year, at the present rate of consumption. I have already pointed out. that some 4,000,000 square feet were cleared from bond at the beginning of the year. The local company claims to have 800,000 square feet of building glass in. stock. Therefore, on the Tariff Board's estimate that 5,000,000 square feet is sufficient to meet the Australian consumption, there should be ample stocks for this year. There are practical difficulties associated with the rationing of imports of glass, as distinct from the rationing of glass in bond. When a portion of that which is in. bond is allowed to be withdrawn at different times, the buyers know what they are getting; but when orders have to be placed overseas, different considerations arise. The board reports that the Government would have to decide as between importers what, quantity of glass should be allotted to each importer in the various sizes, weights, and qualities. It also says that the possibility of the substitution of sizes and weights would present further difficulties, and that the rationing of imports in ratio to the orders placed in any one of the last three years would be impracticable, as artificial conditions existed.
The Government has, therefore, decided -

1. To adopt the Tariff Board's recommendations that the existing duties of 2s. per 100 square feet British and 4s. per 100 square feet general be maintained, and that provision be made for deferred duties of 45 per cent, ad valorem British and 75 per cent, ad valorem general.
2. To refer the matter back to the board for further consideration.
3. To retain the prohibition of the importation of plain clear sheet glass pending the receipt and consideration of the further report.
4. If necessity arises, owing to shortage of supplies, to permit the importation of any quantity shown to be necessary.

I reiterate what I said at the outset - that this is undoubtedly one of the most difficult items in the tariff schedule. The industry has grown up in Australia, and a good deal of capital has been invested in it. I understand that figured, rolled and wired glass, as well as plain sheet glass, is being made. The Government is not desirous of crushing the industry for the sake of avoiding a further inquiry, which should not take long. It is only a matter of the Tariff Board investigating the latest statement that there has been a considerable increase in efficiency and in the quantity and quality of the article produced by the local company. The board will also examine the statement of the importers that the difficulties in connexion with rationing are great. The object of the Government is that the consumer may be enabled to obtain glass at a reasonable price, and that both the importers and the manufacturers shall be able to sell their wares. I intend to move an amendment to give effect to the recommendation of the board in regard to duties.
