Mr. RILEY(Cook) [8.44] . - I am pleased that the Minister and the Government have come to a decision that will enable this industry at least to continue its operations during the difficult and pioneering stage. I confess, however, that I am disappointed at the failure of the Government to give effect to the decision of Parliament in 1925 and 1926, which was fortified by a recommendation of the Tariff Board made in 1925. I was privileged to be a member of this Parliament in 1925, and I have a vivid recollection of the debate that took place following the introduction of the Pratten tariff in that year. I especially recall that, apart from the opposition by several honorable members representing Tasmania and Western Australia to the duties on glass, there was littledisapproval of the proposed deferred duties. Honorable members who were in this Parliament at that time will remember that the recommendation of the Tariff Board was adopted by the then Minister for Trade and Customs (the late Mr. Pratten), and was supported by several who are still in this Parliament, and who, I submit, are in honour bound now to endorse the recommendations of the board on that occasion and the decision of that Parliament.

It should not be necessary for me, as the representative of the electorate in which this important Australian industry is located, to appeal to this Parliament to support it; because the encouragement given to the industry in 1925 was directly responsible for its establishment. My immediate purpose is to endeavour to persuade those honorable members who were in this Parliament in 1925 and voted for the Pratten duties, to realize their responsibilities.

A year or two ago, when the then Premier of New South Wales (Mr. Lang) announced his intention to take a certain course, there was an outcry in this Parliament, and a good deal was said about the evil effects of repudiation. I can imagine no action that would be more detrimental to the interests of this nation, no action that could more appropriately be described repudiation, than the present proposal of the Tariff Board and this Government to deny to the Australian sheet glass industry the protection given to it eight years ago on the recommendation of the Tariff Board as then constituted. As one who followed the debates very closely on that occasion, I declare emphatically that the industry is in existence solely as the result of the deliberate encouragement given by the then Minister for Trade and Customs and the Parliament of that time. I propose to place on record some the statements of the late Mr. Pratten who, I may add, was a Nationalist Minister in a Nationalist and Country party Government. Speaking in the House of Representatives on the 2nd September, 1925, Mr. Pratten said -

I shall endeavour to set before the House the position in the same way as I would if I were a director responsible to my fellow directors and the shareholders of a business. After all, we are the directors of the national interests, and every individual in the Commonwealth is a shareholder, and is interested in and affected by the business of the country . Therefore, as the Minister responsible for the duty of laying upon the table of the House the tariff proposals of the Government, 1 propose to set out the principles which have guided us in arriving at the decisions made. The purposes for which the tariff schedule is created are not always thoroughly appreciated. It is generally thought that it has only two purposes, namely, the protection of primary and secondary industries and the raisins of revenue. There is, however, a further important purpose, for in addition to protecting industries and raising revenue, the tariff is the instrument under which agreements are made with oversea countries, in order to provide markets for our products.

I have pleasure in reading that extract, because I am aware that during this debate some members of the Country party may remind us of the possible consequences to certain primary industries if we exclude Belgian glass. The late Mr. Pratten on that occasion told the committee that a tariff was intended, not only for thu protection of primary and secondary industries and the raising of revenue, but also as an instrument for the making of trade treaties between two or more countries. He went on to say -
One of. the new industries which it is expected will be brought into operation because of the assistance provided in the motion-

That, surely, was an admission that this protection was being given to encourage this particular industry - is that of the manufacture of sheet glass. This valuable industry is under consideration by a strong combination of local interests, and it is expected that, as a result of favorable parliamentary consideration, a further enterprise of considerable importance will be established.

I repeat that, as the direct result of the tariff protection then given, this industry Was established and, I may add, it is now in a position to supply sheet glass equal to the output of any other country. The late Mr. Pratten added-

I believe that £1 worth of value added to raw materials by the secondary producers is equivalent in economic wealth to the Commonwealth to £1 worth of production in any other direction, and that the surest way to keep secondary industries inefficient is to protect them inadequately.

I contend that the proposals now before the committee will, if adopted, seriously injure this efficient Australian industry. Apart from the fact that I was "a member of this chamber when the deferred duties were adopted, as I represent the electorate in which the factory is located, and am, therefore, in close touch with those who are responsible for its development, I realize that it is my personal responsibility to do all in my power to see that the industry is properly safeguarded. I have in my hands a petition, presented by the 240 odd employees, not many of whom are known personally to me, who contend that if adequate protection is withdrawn their future employment will be endangered. Many of the employees, unfortunately, were on the dole before this avenue of employment was opened up to them, and I should be exceedingly sorry if, through any action of this Parliament, they were again thrown out of work. The industry, besides giving employment to a large number of adults, also provides work for scores of lads who, although fitted for other and, possibly, more remunerative employment, are very glad of the chance to work in this factory. At the present time we have over 60 employees engaged in the cutting of sheet glass which previously was imported.
Mr. ArchdaleParkhill. - Who are "we "?

Mr. RILEY.- I am addressing myself to this important question with all the sincerity at my command, and I remind the Postmaster-General (Mr. Parkhill) that I am speaking, not as a shareholder in this concern, but as one who is vitally interested in the development of all Australian industries. The Postmaster-General may laugh and snigger if that gives him any comfort ; but if he has anything to say against this particular industry, I invite him to say it at the earliest opportunity. Possibly the Minister adopts his present attitude because a few growers in his electorate may use horticultural glass for the growing of tomatoes, and consider that their interests are not so well served by the Australian glass company as they would be if they had a free hand to import the glass they require. If the Postmaster-General imagines that the tomato-growers are opposed to the local sheet-glass industry he is hopelessly out-of-date in his information ; the growers are completely satisfied as to price and quality. I prefer to discuss this item on purely national and economic grounds. Up to the present I have made no mention of the 3,000 shareholders who have invested their money in this concern. The adoption of the Tariff Board's recommendation will be tantamount to the repudiation of a deliberate act of this Parliament in 1925-26.

In considering the future of this industry, we should pay regard to its probable effect on our various services. Its expansion will, I suggest, benefit our interstate steamship services, which will obtain revenue from the transport of Australian-made glass. If the industry were not in existence, the transport of imported glass to Australian ports would be carried out by overseas vessels. From the national point of view, is it not desirable to have an efficient interstate shipping service, giving employment to

Australian seamen, profitably engaged in the carriage of Australian goods between Australian seaports, instead of having foreign goods conveyed in foreign vessels? Despite outside propaganda, the opposition to the - development of the sheet-glass industry in Australia is disappearing. It is now confined practically to overseas manufacturers and importers, who always have been opposed to adequate protection being given to this promising Australian industry. When the deferred duties were under consideration a few years ago, the opposition came principally from men who were interested in the distribution of glass. Objection from that quarter has practically vanished. Distributors are now quite satisfied that the local manufacturers can supply glass in quantity and quality equal, if not superior, to the imported article.

It is not my intention to trespass unduly on the time of the committee in the discussion of this item, but I should like to read one or two of the sheaves of letters which I have received from users of Australian glass, all of whom express their entire satisfaction with it.
