Subsequently, he was sued for the amount, a verdict was obtained, and judgment was entered against him. Eventually he was sold up - thanks to the operations of Glass Distributors Limited, which represents, as I have said, both British and foreign manufacturers. Another firm, Bromley, Simpson and Company, was fined £10 for doing business at lower rates than those fixed by Glass Distributors Limited. A. W. Anderson was fined lis. 3d. for selling glass at prices lower than those fixed by this organization. He also had his supplies of plate glass cut off. The Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited had its supplies of plate glass cut off for selling plate glass to firms other than members of the Glass Distributors Limited who are licensed to buy plate glass, and who are approved of by members of the committee. Viner and Waters were fined £1 for a technical breach, namely, selling below list prices. Shores Limited, for selling below the prices fixed by this organization, had uncalled capital' amounting to £475 called up. The matter was contested in court; but, eventually, Glass Distributors Limited were successful, and costs amounting to £250 had to be borne by .Shores Limited. Hoffnung and Company Limited, a firm which has been in business in Sydney for the best part of a century, was regarded at one time by Glass Distributors Limited as an approved house. This recognition carried with it the privilege of being able to buy at 10 per cent, discount; but this right was recently withdrawn, because the firm sold Australian sheet glass at prices less than those stipulated by Glass Distributors Limited. This organization blacklisted a firm which has been established in Pitt-street, Sydney, for 80, years or more.

The report of the Tariff Board, to which the Minister has referred, is six months old ; but, in view of the announcement by the Minister that the matter will be sent back to the Tariff Board, I shall not spend time unnecessarily in dealing with the observations of the board. A period of about six months means a great deal to a new industry, which has experienced the difficulties that this industry has encountered in its pioneering stage. Although the local company has to do certain things, it is in a position to-day to challenge the Tariff Board, the overseas interests, or any local user of frankly admitted that it has been unable glass, to prove its inability to manufacture glass that will be entirely satisfactory both as to quality and quantity. I regret that we have not received from the Tariff Board a report that represents the present position of the industry. I feel that there is some justification for the action that the Minister has taken, and, as a wellwisher of the industry, I welcome the opportunity that will be afforded to it to prove its bona fides, and show the developments that have taken place in connexion with its operations. In view of the statement made by the Minister, there does not appear to be any danger of the board's recommendation as to rationing being carried out. The board estimates Australia's requirements of glass this year to be 5,000,000 square feet, and proposes to permit the importers to supply 3,750,000 square feet, allowing the local manufacturers to provide only 1,250,000 square feet, although they have expended over £300,000 in establishing their industry. I ask myself : Can that be the recommendation of a board of Australians that has been given power by this national Parliament to do a job? I wonder exactly where we stand. I am not anxious, at this juncture, to do anything that would prejudice the industry. I care nothing for political kudos; I would sooner remain silent if by doing so the interests of the industry would be better served. But. I was amazed to read some of the recommendations of the board. Although its report is six months old, the Minister has at his disposal reports by a special investigator from the Customs Department; and through the courtesy of the Minister I have had an opportunity to peruse about four of them. I find from the last report of this investigator that, since the company recommenced production in January last, after rebuilding, repairing and relining its tanks,- it has sold and delivered 1,150,000 square feet of glass, and has accumulated stocks amounting to 1,160,000 square feet, of which over 75 per cent, is of a quality suitable for builders and for picture-framing. Yet the board deals with this industry so contemptuously that it is prepared to allow the importers to supply 3,750,000 square feet, and the local manufacturers only half of the quantity they have produced since they restarted operations in January last. There is no justification for that recommendation.

I must challenge the reference of the honorable member for Perth (Mr. Nairn) to "prevaricating statements" by the local manufacturers. I have been associated with those interested in the local industry from the commencement of its operations, and since the day when the first load of bricks was delivered at the factory site I have taken a special pride in seeing the industry develop. I know something of the difficulties that have had to be surmounted, and of the work done by those men, because of their earnest desire to establish a useful Australian industry. They engaged experts from Belgium and the United States of America, but subsequently found it necessary to dispense with their services, and carry on as best they could without them.. To-day, they have overcome all their difficulties, an achievement for which they should be heartily commended, especially when it is realized that the factory staff is 100 per cent. Australian, and if they were not dependent on the Tariff Board and this Parliament, I should say that their confidence in their ability at the present time to supply Australia Avith an excellent article would justify their being absolutely defiant. They have every confidence in themselves, and they knowexactly the class of article that they can produce. But, unfortunately, the industry is iri the hands of the Tariff Board and this committee. Action could have been taken to remove all doubt as to the success of the industry, without any risk of conflicting with the spirit of the Ottawa agreement, article 10 of which reads -

His Majesty's Government in the Commonwealth of Australia undertake that during the currency of this agreement the tariff shall be based on the principle that protective duties shall not exceed such a level as will give United Kingdom producers full opportunity of reasonable competition on the basis of the relative cost of economical and efficient production, provided that in the application of such principle special consideration may be given to the ease of industries not fully established.

The article which I have just read is surely intended to provide for industries such as the one under discussion. The industry is deserving of the most sympathetic consideration, because this Parliament deliberately encouraged it to spend over £300,000. If I have an opportunity later, I propose to reply to some of the points that will probably be raised; but, in the meantime, I express a certain amount of pleasure in knowing that the industry is to be given a chance to prove its bona fides. I have no doubt that the local company will welcome an opportunity to demonstrate, not what it proposes to do, but what it has already accomplished.

Mr.R. GREEN (Richmond) [9.27].- I have no doubt that many honorable members failed, as I did, to grasp fully the details of the Minister's proposals, and, therefore, I intend to repeat them, the Minister having courteously permitted me to take a note of them. The Government has decided to adopt the Tariff Board's recommendation that the present British preferential duty of 2s. per 100 sq. ft., and the general tariff of 4s. per 100 sq. ft., be maintained, and that on and after the 1st February, 1934, deferred duties of 45 per cent., ad valorem, British, and 75 per cent. general, be imposed. It is also proposed to refer the matter back to the Tariff Board for further consideration; to retain the prohibition of the importation of plain clear sheet glass pending the receipt of a further report from the Tariff Board, and, if the necessity arises, owing to shortage of supplies, to permit the importation of any quantity shown to be necessary. Most honorable members will recognize that this is a most difficult subject. It is admitted that only one factory is engaged in the manufacture of sheet glass in Australia. This matter has been before Parliament on several occasions. It was first raised when the Pratten tariff was introduced in 1926, following a recommendation by the Tariff Board that certain deferred duties be brought into operation. I am among the members of this committee who occupied seats in this Parliament at that time, and we all acquiesced in the imposition of the deferred duties. That promise of Parliament led to the establishment of a company in 1925 to manufacture plain clear sheet glass in Australia. With the passage of time, that company developed to such an extent that it asked the then Minister for Trade and Customs to put the deferred duties into operation. Those duties were entirely different from the Minister's present proposals; instead of being on the basis of 100 square feet, they were fixed on a weight basis - 11/2d. per lb. British, and 2d. per lb. foreign. With other members, I acquiesced in the inclusion of those deferred duties in the tariff schedule in 1925. The company started to manufacture glass, and on the 30th June, 1930, the then Minister for Trade and Customs (Mr. Forde) brought the deferred duties into operation. Since that time several attempts have been made to alter the duties, notwithstanding that Parliament had given a promise that, if the company did certain things, it would be granted a fair measure of protection. The company, believing in the good faith of Parliament, commenced operations; but now, before it can stand by itself, the protection given to it is to be removed. The proposal to remove that protection brings to my mind that ugly word " repudiation ". What is it but repudiation if Parliament does not keep the promise it made to the company in 1925? I remind the committee that because of the repudiation of an agreement - its treatment as a " scrap of paper " - the world suffered a tremendous upheaval not many years ago. With other honorable members in this chamber, I tried to prevent that repudiation. I felt strongly then regarding that act of repudiation; to-night I feel strongly about this attempt to break an agreement. I sincerely hope that Parliament will not repudiate the promise which it gave to this company. Only because Parliament bad passed a tariff schedule granting protection to this industry did the company decide to commence operations. I cannot believe that Parliament will do other than honour its promise. The making of glass is a natural Australian industry; the bulk of the rawmaterials used are obtainable locally. In ease any member of the Country party feels disposed to deprive this industry of protection, I draw attention to the last policy speech of the Leader of the Country party (Dr. Earle Page). While discouraging the establishment of exotic industries, the right honorable gentleman then advocated the protection of natural industries. The Australian Window Glass Company spends large sums of money in Australia. Among the items of expenditure each month are - coal, £1,321; coke, £19; gas, £47; electricity, £272; sulphate of soda, £155; lime, £174; water, £220; sundry manufacturing materials, £77 ; nails, £35 ; cardboard and paper, £20 ; silicat, £S1 ; dolomite, £107 ; Australian timber, £128; clay, £70; refractory bricks, £72; maintenance materials, £550; family endowment tax £.100; insurance and workers' compensation, £84; rates and taxes, £20; and wages, £4,S48. From this one factory the State Government receives each month the following amounts : - Payment for coal supplied, £284 3s. 4d. ; unemployment relief tax, £204 14s.; family endownment tax, £100 18s. 9d.; a total of £589 16s. Id. The company employs about 240 mcn who, but for this industry, would probably be in receipt of the dole. It will, therefore, be seen that this factory is an asset to the country.
Mr. ArchdaleParkhill. - How can the company do all these things, and still make a profit on its £300,000 capital?

Mr. R.GREEN.- Had the Postmaster-General been present at a deputation which waited on the Attorney-General (Mr. Latham) last week, he would have heard the managing director of the company answer a similar question. I shall be pleased to supply the information to the Postmaster-General later.

I have been asked to state the price of the glass manufactured by this company. I have not been able to obtain figures for the years prior to 1925, when the Tariff Board made its first inquiry. At that time, sheet glass .was not manufactured in Australia. According to figures which were tendered in evidence before the Tariff Board in 1925, British 16-oz. glass then cost 27s. and Belgian glass 23s. per 100 sq. ft. In 192S, after the deferred duties had been put on, but before the Australian factory was built, imported glass was sold in Australia for 27s. 6d. per 100 sq. ft. At that time, the exchange rate was normal, and there was no primage duty. The f.o.b. price of glass in 1925 remained practically constant till the Forde duties were imposed in 1930. At that time the Australian company had not commenced to manufacture glass. In 1932, British glass was offered at about 12s. and Belgian glass at about 8s. 6d. per 100 sq. ft. f.o.b. A recent quotation gave Belgian glass as 7s. 6d. per 100 sq. ft. f.o.b., but I do not know whether it can be obtained at that price. The price of British glass is now about the same as it was in 1932. The only figure with which we should be concerned is the cost of glass to its actual users. As I have said, British glass was offered at 12s. per 100 sq. ft. f.o.b. in 1932. At that time, Australian glass had not come on to. the market to any great extent. The glass merchants in Australia charged 56s. (id. per 100 sq. ft. at that time, but shortly after the Australian Window Glass Company commenced operations, it offered glass at 28s. 3d. per 100 sq. ft. - exactly half the amount charged for the imported glass - notwithstanding the primage and other duties on imported soda ash.
Mr. Holloway.- There was no Australian monopoly then.

Mr. R.GREEN.- If there was, it reduced the price of glass by 50 per cent. The price of imported glass to-day is 56s. 6d. less 33-;\ per cent., less 5 per cent., or a net amount of 35s. per 100 sq. ft. It is evident that the Australian community has been exploited. Prior to the establishment of the Australian company, glass which was valued at 12s. per 100 sq. ft. f.o.b. British ports, cost 56s. 6d. in Australia. The present price of Australian glass is 28s. 3d. per 100 sq. ft., compared with about 30s. in New Zealand, where glass is admitted duty free. These figures must convince the committee that the establishment of the Australian Window Glass Company has conferred a material benefit on Australia. Honorable members must be surprised at the condition of affairs to which the honorable member for Cook (Mr. Riley) drew attention. I am reliably informed that, as the result of a merger, the firm of Pilkington Brothers Limited is the only large glass-making company in Great Britain. There was also an arrangement between that firm and the Belgian and American companies to form a combine, and, given the chance, those organizations would again exploit this country as they did in the past. Our only safeguard is the existence of a glass factory in Australia. In the 1932 report of the Tariff Board, Mr. Norbury is quoted as saying that " sheet glass can only be made economically in large quantities ". With that honorable members will agree; it is for that reason that there is only one glass factory in Australia. The Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited has invested £300,000 in its business, and, with the assistance of protective duties, has formed what may be termed a combine. But is it not better to have a combine which we can control rather than to be subjected to the operations of an overseas combine which is beyond our control, for we can control the local combine by reducing or withdrawing the duty, also through the medium of taxation.

As to the prices charged, the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited has arranged for the distribution of builders' quality glass in the country at 38s. a single box of 100 square feet, or in 25 box lots, at 303. a box. Imported glass of a similar quality is being sold in Australia at 56s. 6d. a box. The -company has also protected the public from exploitation in regard to figured rolled glass. At a recent deputation the Attorney-General asked a question similar to that asked of me to-night by the Postmaster-General. I point out that the manufacture of figured rolled glass is a sideline, without which it is doubtful whether the company could carry on under existing conditions. I sincerely hope that the committee will accept the proposals of the Minister, which, after all, will merely mean deferring the matter pending the receipt of a report from the Tariff Board. I hope that on this occasion that board will he asked to report on the quality and price of the local article, also the quantity that can be manufactured. Some samples of the Australian product have been placed on the front Opposition bench, and 1 urge honorable members to compare them with the glass that may be seen in the doors of the corridors at the Hotel Canberra, an imported article which was passed by our architects as first-class builders' glass.
Mr. Prowse.- Is it first class?

Mr. R.GREEN.- It certainly is not, although it was sold as such. There should be no difficulty in the way of the Tariff Board thoroughly examining the 1,000,000 square feet of glass which is now in stock at the factory of the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited, whose product is sold on the guarantee that it is equal to or better than the imported article. Regarding quantity of production, Australia's annual requirement of builders' glass is 5,000,000 square feet, and the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited is capable of manufacturing 12,000,000 square feet per annum. That company has not asked this Government to share any of the burdens borne by it as a result of the depression in the building and associated trades. It regards them as a business risk. All that it asks is' that the Government should honour the promise, on the strength of which its factory was erected. In turn, it will fulfil the obligations that it undertook and produce the whole of Australia's ' requirements, guaranteeing satisfaction in regard to both quality and price.

Mr. HUGHES(North Sydney) [9.55]. - In his opening remarks, the Minister for Trade and Customs (Mr. White) said that the Government had found that the rates of duty on plain sheet glass presented many difficulties. I can quite believe that difficulties are created by the very nature of the industry, and by the experiences through which it has passed. But the issue that we have to decide is perfectly clear; whether we intend to encourage an Australian or a Belgian industry. The Ottawa agreement do*? not come into the matter. A close examination of the position proves conclusively that, while there are British glass manufacturing firms, they are under the control and part of the Belgian combination. In order to indicate how Belgium controls the sheet-glass industry, let me quote from a brochure that was issued by the International Labour Office at Geneva in 1933, an entirely impartial review, which deals with " Methods of providing rest and alternation of shifts in automatic sheet-glass works," and states, at page 23 -

Thus, the sheet-glass industry is highly concentrated. Not only do powerful firms like the Societe des brevets Fourcault, and the Compagnie Internationale pour la fabrication mécanique du verre own the rights of working the Fourcault and Libbey-Owens patents, as the case may bc, but undertakings using the same process are frequently under a common management. In Belgium, for example, firms equipped on the Fourcault system, originally separate undertakings, combined on the 31st December, 1930, to form the Union des verreries mécaniques beiges S.A. a.t Charleroi, and production is thus definitely concentrated from the administrative, technical and commercial points of view.

Belgium has 194 Fourcault and 18 Libbey-Owens machines, a greater number than is possessed by all the other glassmaking concerns in Europe put together. The industry is highly concentrated, and is completely controlled by a monopoly which has its head-quarters in Belgium. In 1930, the International Labour Office submitted a questionnaire to the .Australian Government, in which it ' was asked whether- automatic glass manufacture was established in the Commonwealth. The reply was in the negative. Since then, of course, conditions have changed; I merely point out that the International Labour Office was given to understand that no automatic glass manufacture was established here. The extent to which mechanization has been carried in the industry is indicated by the following paragraphs which appear at page 27 of the brochure: -
One large sheet-glass works has only twenty glass workers properly so-called out of a total staff of TOO.

The hours of work in the glass factories of Belgium are 56 weekly; in those of Czechoslovakia, 48; and in those of France, 48. The conditions in the Belgian factories are bad. This industry is so highly mechanized that out of 700 employees only twenty are skilled mechanics. As the honorable member for Richmond (Mr. R. Green) has pointed out, the f.o.b. price of Belgian glass in 1925, before the Australian industry was established, was 23s. per 100 sq. ft., whereas it has been quoted recently at 7s. 6d. per 1Q0 sq. ft. This shows the extent to which the Belgian monopoly had been profiting by its Australian trade.

The Minister has said that the world has been compelled to recognize that no nation can live for itself alone. That is quite true, but nations must live. The question is: How shall they live? We must find some happy medium between isolation and promiscuity. Britain has been forced to recognize that she must look after her own industries. While other nations have been living for themselves alone, Britain has been living for others. In these days, however, nations must look after themselves. While Britain Was neglecting this duty her industries were SlOWlY sinking to ruin. The only British industry which
Was able to maintain, itself through the darkest days of the slump was the motor industry, which Was sheltered by the Safety of Industries Act.

Another question Ave have to ask ourselves is: What effect will the policy of the Government have upon employment and prices on the sheet-glass industry, and on the investment of money in industry generally? Then, too, it is a truism that we must prevent imports rising above a certain level. Otherwise we shall be back where we were at the end of 1930, and be compelled to resort to the drastic expedients applied by the Scullin Government to correct the position. It is undeniable that our imports of glass come from a country to which we owe no allegiance whatever. If we were to give to every country what it deserved, we should give very much to Great Britain and absolutely nothing to Belgium. Belgium owes a great deal to us. There are more Australian soldiers lying in graves in. Belgium than there were Belgian soldiers killed in Belgium in the Great War. So I say that Belgium owes a very great deal to us, and we owe nothing whatever to Belgium. Belgium has control of the glass-making industry, and proposes to keep control of it.

The report of the Tariff Board on this industry is not so convincing as we would desire. The honorable member for Richmond epitomized the report in the concluding words of his speech. He said that three points had to be considered: Can this industry produce the quantity of glass required; is the quality of the glass good, and is the price of the product satisfactory? These are all matters of fact in the determination of which we should exercise our own intelligence. The evidence given before the Tariff Board was from highly prejudiced parties on both sides. The manufacturers and the importers alike wore out to present the best case they could for themselves. Looking at the glass manufactured in Australia, I am bound to say, as an uninitiated layman, that it seems to be quite good. The" honorable member for Cook (Mr. Riley) said that some of the glass in Hotel Canberra supplied by the Belgian combine had a ripple in it, and so was not good. I do not know that the Tariff Board is able to express an expert opinion on this subject. What more does it know about glass than honorable members do?

We have also to consider the effect that this change of duty will have upon this industry, and upon employment generally. The Minister has advanced the board's suggestion that employment in the industry should be rationed; but the general manager of the company has pointed out that that is an absurd proposition. The capacity of this firm is 12,000,000 square feet per annum, and it now has S00,000 square feet in store. To ask it to confine its production to* 1,250,000 square feet per annum is ridiculous. If glass is to be turned out from this factory by its* highly mechanized process at economic prices, the plant must be kept in continuous work throughout the year. Otherwise, it cannot produce cheap glass. It would be better for the factory to close down than for it to limit its production of glass to 1,250,000 feet per annum. We must say either that the factory shall close down, or that the industry shall be protected and encouraged. There can he no half measures. We must determine whether we shall support the Belgian or the Australian industry. The Australian industry is conducted under good conditions and its employees, receive good wages; whereas the Belgian industry is conducted under bad conditions, and its employees receive poor wages.

We must further ask ourselves what effect this reduction of duty is likely to have upon the investment of money in industry in this country. We should encourage people to invest their money in industry. The trouble to-day is that people are afraid to do so. There is plenty of money in the banks, but people will not invest it in industry, because they have no assurance of a fair return. The sum of £300,000 has been invested in the Australian glass manufacturing industry, and the industry is being conducted at a high pitch of efficiency. Not even the Tariff Board can quite gainsay that. I have no doubt that before this sheet glass, manufacturing company began operations in Australia it was given some undertaking that it would be supported. The general manager of the company has made it clear that he' was given to understand that the policy of Australia was that Australian industries would be protected and encouraged. When I was in London, some years ago, a representative of Babcock and Wilcox Limited, waited on me and asked whether I could give give him an assurance that if his firm established itself in Australia, suitable duties would bc provided to protect it against outside competition. I said that I could not give him that assurance, but I could assure him that the policy of Australia was the encouragement of Australian industries. The result was that the firm began operations in Australia. No doubt the company which embarked upon the manufacture of glass in Australia was given a similar assurance that Australian industries would be protected. But the Government now proposes to change that policy. Such a change of policy will certainly deter people from investing their money in Australian industries. The Minister stated that the Tariff Board had reported that a continuance of the duties that existed at the time it made its report would increase building costs; but the only evidence that I can find in the board's report to support such a statement is that given by Mr. Smith, that the extra cost of the glass required for a six-roomed house was only ls. 6d. That trifling possibility surely should not affect us in our judgment. We are confronted with certain facts which, I admit, are capable of many interpretations; but, as I stated this morning at a deputation, we are as capable as the members of the Tariff Board of making a decision on the facts. The board does not deny that this industry is thoroughly efficient and capable of turning out good glass. It is not. denied that tha company has turned out or can turn out sufficient glass for our requirements, nor that the Government lias some measure of control over an Australian company. If the company were to exploit the public, regulations could bc framed to meet the position. No regulations within the legislative ambit of the Commonwealth could prevent exploitation by foreign importers. In all the circumstances, I can see no reason why the present conditions should not be allowed to continue - at least, until the Tariff Board makes its final investigation of this industry. Every investigation of the board apparently brings it nearer to the point at which it will be able to give the company a clean bill, of health. After its first inquiry t he board reported that the Australian product left, something to bc desired. That can be easily understood. It applies to any industry in the early days of its existence. The board has since reported that the Australian product has been wonderfully improved. In the circumstances, I suggest that it is reasonable to ask the Government to hold its hand until the board rnakes the investigation that has been promised.

I am strongly averse to striking a blow at this industry. It appears to me that we are determining to-night something more . than the fate of this particular enterprise. We arc determining whether we shall support Australian or foreign industry. It is not a. question of the encouragement of trade between Australia and Great Britain. If it were, I should look at it through different eyes. The question is whether we shall encourage an Australian or a Belgian industry. I have no hesitation in declaring on which side I shall array myself. While I am willing to make many concessions, and to go a long way to help British industry, I am not prepared to go a yard to help Belgian industry, or the industry of any other foreign country. Our clear duty is first to our fellow citizens, next to our kinsmen overseas, and then to the world at large. This being so, I propose to register' my vote on behalf of my fellow citizens.

Mr. FORDE(Capricornia) [10.15].- The honorable member for Richmond (Mr. R. Green) is to be commended for having taken the trouble to visit the factory of the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited. As a result of his investigation of every phase of the industry, he is prepared to give it his whole-hearted support. If other members of the Country party would follow his example, and acquaint themselves with - the wonderful development that has taken place in Australian secondary industries, they, too, would be more ready to do justice to them. I am pleased that the Government has decided to extend the embargo against the importation of glass for a period of twelve months without any rationing, so long as the stocks in Australia, are sufficient to supply requirements. I do not think there will be much doubt that adequate supplies will be available. It is estimated that 4,000,000 square feet of sheet glass is stored in the warehouses, whilst the Australian manufac.turers have over 1,000,000 square feet in stock, and during the period of the embargo will, be able, if working only half time, to supply at least another 5,000,000 or G,000,000 square feet. These quantities in the aggregate will be sufficient to supply the Australian demand for probably two years. I believe that, as a result of further investigations by the Tariff Board, the Australian manufacturers will bo able to satisfy that body in regard to the quality, supply, and price of their product. The honorable member for Cook (Mr. Riley), in whose electorate this efficient factory is located, has read testimonials from representatives of the building trade and the tomato-growers that the quality of Australian sheet glass is all that can be desired. I am particularly impressed by the testimony of Mr. H. E. Ross, representing the Institute of Architects of New South Wales -

My examination was quite impartial in that respect, and it was comparative ... In making this comparison, I would like to say that I regarded the Australian-made glass, which I investigated in sheets in the works - sheets picked at random, and in many cases covered with dust, the accumulation of some weeks - as being distinctly superior to the average of the not identified imported glass.

The manufacturers guarantee the local glass to be equal, if not superior, to the corresponding glasses imported from abroad. At an earlier inquiry by the Tariff Board the representative of the principal British manufacturing company condemned in unmeasured terms the Fourcault process used by the Australian manufacturers, and said that they would not bo able to produce by this means a glass good enough for this market. This process, which originated in Belgium, was copied by the manufacturers at Pittsburg, United States of America, and has since been adopted by the English company, whose representative in Australia had previously condemned it. The Minister stated to-night that the Australian manufacturers would not be able to get rid of the large proportion of reject glass in their output, whereas manufacturers abroad had the whole world in which to sell their output. The prices of Belgian and British cheap glasses are, per 100 square feet, 8s. 6d. and 12s. 6d. respectively. If the Minister's contention is correct, how will Great Britain he able to sell its reject ;:lass in competition with the cheaper product of Belgium? The manufacture of glass is becoming highly specialized, and through the adoption of improved methods the proportion of reject glass is steadily declining. As far back as five years ago glass of 70 Der cent. quality was being turned out. A rejection of 20 per cent, would not be considered' phenomenal in glass production generally. The Australian Glass Company - the parent of the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited - is to be commended for its enterprise and efficiency. We hear it condemned as a monopoly, but I would prefer a monopoly which gives employment to Australian people, and over which we can exercise some control, rather than be at the mercy of a foreign organization operating in other parts of the world aud able to impose its will on Australia. It is a combine with world-wide ramifications that is resisting the establishment of sheet glass manufacture in the Commonwealth. Pilkington^, who have an absolute monopoly in Great Britain of the manufacture of 'both sheet and plate glass, are allied with the big Belgian companies; in fact, the English and continental interests are linked, and one at least, of the most powerful American companies is working in conjunction with the Belgian manufacturers. When the Scullin Government was in office it found that the Australian Glass Company could not commence operations with the duties still deferred. Importers were accumulating large stocks of glass from overseas, sufficient to meet Australia's requirements for at least twelve months ahead, and while this continued no market, could be found for the output of any Australian factory. Before the local glass could be sold the accumulated stocks in the warehouses had to be disposed of, and action had to be taken to create conditions under which a market would be possible when local manufacture began. On the 19th June, 1930, the Scullin Government, after satisfying itself that there was sufficient' sheet glass in the country to meet all demands for at. least a year ahead, introduced a tariff proposal, that abolished the deferred provisions and imposed, the full rate of duty recommended by the Tariff Board in 1925, and approved by the Bruce Page Government, but deferred from time to time. The action taken hy the Scullin Government was the only means of checking the importations which were maintaining warehouse stocks to such an extent as to prevent local manufacture. When I was Minister for Trade and Customs this industry gave me a great deal of concern. We were confronted with" the problem of widespread unemployment, and as the establishment of this industry presented an opportunity to increase employment, I make no apology for having decided to give preference to Australian capital and labour over manufacturers in other countries. The Australian Glass Company, having £300,000 of capital to invest, could have undertaken the manufacture of sheet glass in Belgium or Great Britain or some other country where labour is cheap, but it bought the Australian rights in the Fourcault process and proceeded to establish a new enterprise in this country. Having invested its money, it was entitled to expect that it would get adequate protection against importations of foreign or even British glass. Now it is employing 240 persons. The representative of the workers- at a deputation to the Prime Minister said that he had been on the dole for twelve months, and that a number of his fellows had been on the dole for two years, but were now in employment. Are we going to continue their employment or to send our orders to overseas manufacturers, who prior to the action taken by the Scullin Government, had been exploiting the Australian market? The factory of the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited is admitted by experts to be one of the most up to date in the world, and it is manufacturing plain sheet, opal, figured rolled, milled rolled, roughcast, wired cast, and opalescent glasses. This is not an industry for a small struggling company. It requires the resources of a big organization such as the Australian Glass Company. This parent organization has nine factories - four in New South Wales, two in Victoria, and one in each of the other States, except Tasmania: it has a capital of £2,000,000, is employing 2,400 persons, and will soon be employing 3,000 persons if the protection is continued. Inquiries made by the Trade and Customs Department, when I was Minister, elicited the fact that immediately the increased duties were imposed importing and distributing firms raised their prices by an amount equivalent to the higher duties. Huge stocks had been imported by these firms, and the duty paid thereon was at the nominal rates of 2s. and 4s. per 100 square feet. The difference between the former duties and the increased duties was taken from the pockets of the people by the importers who protest loudly that their hearts bleed for the users of glass. The right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) said that some encouragement must have been given to the Australian Glass Company to embark upon the manufacture of sheet glass. The Bruce-Page Government, in which Mr. Pratten was Minister for Trade and Customs, told this, company that it would refer the matter to the Tariff Board for investigation and report. The matter was referred to the board, and the board recommend-sd deferred duties which the Bruce-Page Government put into the- tariff schedule, and which were, subsequently, put into operation by the Scullin Government. The fact that the Bruce-Page Government put the deferred duties into the tariff schedule was an earnest to the company of the Government's intentions.
Mr. GREGORY- Why was not the Tariff Board asked to report before the deferred duties were made operative?

Mr. FORDE.- I shall deal with that matter in a moment. I am now dealing with the Tariff Board's report of 1925. Although half of the members of the Cabinet at that time were members of the Country party, the Government inserted in the schedule deferred duties of 1-1 d. per lb., British, and 2d. per lb., foreign, or the alternative ad valorem rates. Surely this company with its intelligent advisers, knowing that the policy of this country was to provide adequate protection for Australian industries, had reason to believe there was no need for it to plead or beg for protection. The fact that this industry when established would give employment to our own people, and would supply a market which was formerly supplied by foreigners, was quite sufficient to merit the granting of adequate protection to it. In 1925, when Mr. Pratten introduced Lis proposal for a deferred duty on sheet, glass, he quoted from the Tariff Board's report the following statement : -

It is very desirable to have established in the Commonwealth industries whose products arc in general demand by our population and which permit of production on a large scale, as by this means Australia's capacity to absorb a larger population and to make possible greater immigration was considerably increased. In addition, there is the advantage of adding to the domestic consumption nf primary and other products by the consequential greater population.

The Tariff Board of 1925 and the Minister of the day were strong protectionists. That cannot be said of the board as constituted to-day. As a result, of conversations with the representatives of the Government, this company went ahead with its proposal to expend £300,000 in building an up-to-date factory. The present Minister, in the course of his speech this evening, said that when I was Minister I prohibited the importation of glass. If the Minister will, refer to the officials of his department, he will find that that was not the case. According to the Tariff Board's summary of happenings in connexion with duties on glass, its recommendation to lower the duty from Hd. per lb. British, and 2d. per lb. foreign, or 45 per cent, and 60 per cent., respectively, to 2s. per 100 sq. ft. British, and 4s. per 100 sq. ft. foreign, was given effect to by customs tariff proposals No. 6, tabled, on the 1st September, 1932. The summary also shows the following : -

On the 23rd September, 1932, which is also the dato on which the matter was again referred to the board, a proclamation was issued prohibiting the importation of plain, clear sheet glass unless the consent in writing of the Minister for Trade and Customs had first been obtained.

That action was taken, not by me as Minister in the last Government, but by the honorable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr. Perkins), Assistant Minister for Trade and Customs in the present Government. Subsequently, steps were taken by the present Government (o ration imports. So far as I can remember, imports of glass were not prohibited in any way by the last Administration, but it made operative the deferred duties put into the tariff schedule by the Bruce-Page Government. When the duties of l£d. per lb. and 2d. per lb. were in effect, and glass was being sold in Sydney at 56s. 6d. per 100 sq. ft., the Australian Window Glass Company cut the price in half, and sold its product to the user for 28s. 3d. per :100 sq. ft. That company has been criticized because it imported and sold window glass before it commenced to manufacture that commodity here. But there was good reason for that. Following upon the decision of the company to undertake the manufacture of window glass, it engaged in the importation and sale of window glass manufactured overseas by the Fourcan lt system. It showed wisdom in doing that, because it wanted to establish not only a trade in this commodity but also a selling organization and goodwill, so that when it started to manufacture window glass in Australia by this process there would be a steady demand for it. It is quite natural that there should he strong opposition to this company from the overseas manufacturers who for many years had had an unrestricted business in Australia. The local company employs Australians, and has plant and equipment capable of supplying the whole of the Australian demand. The importation of window glass by the Australian Glass Company has been referred to as an attempt to exploit the Australian public, but any impartial person must admit that the importations were made to enable the company to build up a connexion with clients in glass of a class similar to what it intended to manufacture here. The company did not increase its prices. Any increase that took place was made by the importers, who held large stocks in warehouses in Australia. For a time, the local company was severely criticized for _ not manufacturing glass, but, naturally, it was waiting for a demand for its goods, and that was not likely to eventuate while huge stocks were held in the warehouses. The honorable member for Swan (Mr. Gregory) has asked why the Scullin Government . put the deferred duty into operation on the 19th June, 1930,. when, in the ordinary course, it would not have become operative until the 1st August of that year. The reason is that glass was being imported at such a rate that, unless the importations were checked, the Australian market could have been supplied for at least two years ahead. The stocks in hand at that time were sufficient for twelve months supply, so that when the deferred duties were put into operation, there was no danger whatever of any shortage taking place. Had the local company waited until the stocks were depleted, it could not have obtained a footing in the Australian market.
Mr. Gregory.- The Tariff Board Act provides that the board must submit a report before deferred duties are put into operation.

Mr. FORDE.-Why should the Government have subordinated itself to the Tariff Board at a time of great national crisis, when this country had an adverse trade balance and hundreds of thousands of people were out of work? The government of the day had to assume responsibility by taking decisive action to stem the tide of imports. In the circumstances, there was no necessity for it to wait for the report of the Tariff Board, and I make no apology for the action of the Scullin Government at that time. The" present Government is continuing the embargo for twelve months, but all that the Scullin Government did was to put into operation the deferred duties which had been placed in the tariff schedule by the Bruce-Page Government. The Postmaster-General (Mr. Parkhill), at the time I was Minister, showed great concern for tomato-growers. He said that they were being mulcted to the extent of hundreds of thousands of pounds because of the duties placed on imported glass. What is the actual position? Since the local manufacturer has been supplying the Australian market, the price of glass for horticultural purposes has been reduced from 50s. to 25s. per 100 square feet. The tomato-growers have now no difficulty in obtaining their requirements in Australia.

As the Minister for Trade and Customs has decided to impose a total prohibition on imports for a period of twelve months, and to refer the matter back to the Tariff Board for investigation, I arn confident that, in view of the increased efficiency of the company, its capacity to supply Australian requirements, and the reasonable prices that it is charging for its product, it will have no difficulty in convincing the Tariff Board of its need for protection, and that the board will make a favorable report. In the circumstances, the Opposition in this chamber is prepared to let the matter stand over for the present. I regret that the Government did not see fit to give adequate protection to the manufacturers of cut crystal , glass, which, of course, is a luxury line. With proper protection, the Crown Crystal "Glass Company would employ 300 additional hands. When the Scullin Government introduced its tariff schedule, this company was employing 200 hands, butsoon afterwards, the number increased to S50. I am sorry that the present Government has failed to give adequate protection to that branch of the glass industry. In view of the fact that the matter is being referred to the Tariff Board, I feel confident that the industry will be able to justify itself, and that the men employed in the. window-glass factory will not be dismissed. 1

Mr.JENNINGS (South Sydney) [10.44]. - I quite agree that this item, upon which so many varied opinions 'have been expressed, constitutes one of the most difficult problems facing the Government. I have a knowledge of many aspects of the glass industry, and have endeavoured to analyse the position in order to come to a fair decision. I venture to say that most of the troubles of this industry have arisen because of a battle royal which has waged between the local manufacturing interests on the one hand, and the importing and distributing interests on the other; but it is not too late now for them to come together in order that the large amount of money which has been invested in this national industry should be conserved, and some hundreds of Australians kept directly and indirectly in employment. It has been suggested inside this chamber, and I think outside of it, that the local manufacturers have exploited the public. It has been stated that the Australian Glass Manufacturing Company, when an increased duty was mooted, stocked its warehouses with importations and, after the passing of the Scullin Tariff, unloaded its stocks on to the public at greatly enhanced prices. That is a most damaging statement, which has undoubtedly inflamed the minds of the public. If any honorable member can bring evidence to prove that commercial immorality of this description has been practised by this firm, I am prepared to withdraw my support of the protection given to the industry. The recently submitted report of the Tariff Board may be regarded as out of date, in view of the considerable progress that has been made in the production of Australian glass during the last six months. In 1925, Parliament decided to give adequate protection to this industry, and, as a consequence, a capital of £300,000 was invested in it. If tha report of the Tariff Board is given full effect, the industry will be annihilated, with the result that capital to the extent of £300,000 will be lost, many hundreds of Australians will be thrown out of employment, and the plans and organization for the manufacture of Australian glass, which is the product of Australian brains, and is approved of by the

Australian people,will be rendered abortive. The present Australian requirements of glass amount to 5,000,000 square feet per annum, and the Tariff Board proposes that permission be granted for the importation of 3,500,000 sq. ft. Importations to that extent would throttle the local industry. The present position is, that the Australian glass manufacturers have four months' supply on hand; that they can manufacture up to 12,000,000 sq. ft. per annum ; and that, if given three months' notice to enable them to manufacture the necessary machinery in Australia, the production can be raised to as high a figure as 20,000,000 sq. ft. Therefore, the industry is able to produce far in excess of Australian demands. I have before me two small sheets of glass, one a piece of imported plate glass and the othera piece of thick Australian sheet glass. The imported plate glass of a kind not manufactured here carries a revenue duty of 15s., while the duty on plain sheet glass, such as is manufactured in Australia, is 4s. I doubt if any honorable member can say which is the Australian sheet glass and which the imported glass. I can tell the difference only because it has been pointed out to me by an expert. The revenue duty definitely increases the cost to the user to the full extent of the duty; yet imported plate glass is to be found in tens of thousands of buildings in Australia to-day, and no complaints are made. The imposition of the protective duty proposed under the latest tariff, however, will not add materially to the cost. The Australian sheet glass used in a six-roomed cottage would cost only 1s. 6d. more than the price charged for imported glass paying the old duties three years ago, when exchange was normal, the additional1s. 6d. being made up by primage duty and exchange on the raw material used in the manufacture of the glass. As the honorable member for Richmond (Mr. R. Green) has stated, the price of imported glass three years ago was 27s. 6d., while to-day the price of Australian sheet glass is 28s. 3d.

I contend that a case has been made out for the continuation of this industry. It has justified its existence so far as price and supply are concerned, and from the many letters that I have perused I am convinced that there is no doubt in regard to quality. If a similar position existed in any other country, in view of the economic conditions adequate protection would be given to an industry of this character. Until world conditions change, Australia must act in like manner.

Mr.PATERSON (Gippsland) [10.50]. - In regard to the duties on sheet glass, I believe that the Government has come to the only possible decision, namely, to accept for the time being the recommendation of the Tariff Board to leave the duty at 2s. British and 4s. general, per 100 feet and to refer the matter back to the board, so that the advice that it tenders may be based on the very latest information available. If the big advance claimed has been made by this industry during the last few months, it is only fair to the industry that the Tariff Board should be informed of it.

There is one point to which I would allude which has not been mentioned by those who have already spoken; that is, the very heavy capital expenditure in the industry. It appears to me that this enterprise is hopelessly over-capitalized, considering the possibilities of output in a country like Australia. We are told in the Tariff Board's report that capital to the extent of some £300,000 has been invested in the industry. At 6 per cent., the amount, needed for interest alone would be £18,000. I assume, also, that 6 per cent. is a moderate amount to allow for depreciation in an industry which, the Tariff Board says, has to close down for overhaul for a few weeks every six months. That would represent a further £18,000, making £36,000 for interest and depreciation on a capital of £300,000. Assuming this company produced the whole of the 5,000,000 square feet of glass required at the present time in Australia, interest, on capital and depreciation would absorb 14s. per 100 square feet.
Mr. Scullin.- The honorable member is not aware that, with the same plant, this company is also making rolled and figured glass.

Mr. PATERSON.-According to my calculation, the industry is over-capitalized. If it is to sell at a reasonable price, and make interest on its capital, that capital will have to be very drastically written down.
Mr. Fenton.- Five million square feet is not the normal Australian requirement.

Mr. PATERSON.- Even under normal conditions, Australia is not capable of taking such immense quantities as would provide reasonable interest and working expenses in an industry that is so hopelessly over-capitalized, and I can see no escape from a very heavy writing down. The 14s. which is necessary to produce 6 per cent. interest and 6 per cent. depreciation with an output of 5,000,000 square feet, is greater than was the cost of Belgian glass landed in store, free of duty, before the exchange rate rose, and represents half of the company's present price of 28s. per 100 square feet. This must give any one reason to pause, in considering the future of this company.

A good deal has been said to-night concerning importing monopolists, and the opportunity that has been taken by glassdistributing firms to raise their prices under the very heavy duty imposed two years ago by the previous Government. The Tariff Board admits that advantage was taken of that duty by certain firms, and that, when the opportunity was given to them, they raised their prices to a replacement cost basis. But I would point out that, while profiteering of that kind is undoubtedly possible under very heavy duties, or the operation of an embargo, it is not possible in this particular industry when normal imports are permitted, because any person requiring from twenty boxes upwards can indent them himself. I admit that that does not get over the difficulty of a monopoly on the other side of the world manipulating the price. The fact remains, however, that in normal times the buyer in Australia is not at the mercy of local distributing firms. That is made clear in the report of the board, which at page 10 says -
This was made plain by Mr. A. F. Duff, representing Brooks Robinson Proprietary Limited -
Question.- Can any considerable user get the right to order under that basis?
Answer.- Any one. We will take indent orders from any man that wants to order twenty boxes or more; not less than twenty boxes. He can buy as cheap as the cheapest buyer.
The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Forde) spoke of 3,000 workers being employed in the glass industry. He must have included those who are engaged in the glass bottle industry.

Mr. Forde.- I said that 2,400 were employed at present by the holding company, and that 3,000 will be employed shortly in the whole of the industry, which embraces nine factories - four in New South Wales, and one in each of the other States except Tasmania.

Mr. PATERSON.-We are dealing only with the window glass industry, which employs only one-tenth of the numbers quoted by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) said that we owe nothing to Belgium; but that Belgium owes us a great deal. He also stated that he would be prepared to make some sacrifice in dealing with Great Britain in trade matters, but not in dealing with a country like Belgium. It is perfectly true - in a sense other than the one intended by the right honorable gentleman - that we owe nothing to Belgium, and that Belgium owes us a great deal. According to the latest figures that I have in my possession, during 1928-29 Belgium purchased from us goods to the value of nearly £10,000,000, while the value of our purchases from Belgium was only about £1,000,000. The question arises, how are they going to pay us if we do not take from them some of the goods which, in the past, they have exported?
Mr. Fenton.- The right honorable gentleman was speaking in a wider sense.
Mr. PATERSON.- Doubtless he was. That country owes us, on the figures I have quoted, about £10,000,000 per annum for Australian goods purchased. Are we to deny her the opportunity to pay us?
Mr. Scullin.- Belgium's unfavorable trade balance with Australia is balanced through other countries from which we buy.

Mr. PATERSON.-I am aware of the usual procedure for the balancing of international trade accounts; but the fact is that Belgium buys from Australia about ten times as much as Australia buys from Belgium, and I think it was unwise on the part of the right honorable member for North Sydney to speak disparagingly of that country. The right honorable gentleman also asked what would be the effect of this deferred duty upon this new Australian industry. We might very well ask how the extremely high protective duties in this tariff will affect Belgium which, in 1928- 29, bought from Australia £5,686,000 worth of greasy wool, £750,000 worth of scoured wool, £263,000 worth of zinc concentrates, £686,000 worth of pig lead, £250,000 worth of wheat, and nearly £500,000 worth of frozen beef, as well as very many other commodities, all of which were admitted duty free. May I remind the committee that Belgium has a very substantial tariff on a number of the commodities which, in the year mentioned, were brought from Australia? For example, the duty on frozen beef is 30 francs per 100 kilogrammes; on scoured wool it is "15 francs; on pig lead it is 12 francs; and there are varying rates on many other goods which Australia supplies. Is it reasonable to expect that Belgium will continue to keep our products on the free list if we approve of the attitude of the right honorable member for North Sydney? There are two sides to this question. Many honorable members, I think, forget that in an endeavour to do something for Australian trade in one particular direction we may, perhaps, be closing existing markets to Australian trade in another direction. If Belgium imposed a duty of only 1 per cent, on the wool which she imports from Australia, the amount involved would bo much greater than the total value of the glass industry to this country.
Mr. Rosevear.- Does Belgium buy our" wool merely to help us?

Mr. PATERSON.- I have no doubt that Belgium buys our wool because she needs it for her industries. But that is no reason why we should not, in our tariff policy, pay some regard to the interests of such a valuable customer. I shall support the Government in accepting, for the time being, the recommendation of the Tariff Board, and in referring this matter back to that body for further inquiry.

Mr. STACEY(Adelaide) [11.5].- ! am pleased to know that the Minister (Mr. White) intends to refer the duties on sheet glass back to the Tariff Board for further inquiry. I feel sure that the board will find the position to be very different from what it was six months ago. In the early part of last year I was receiving almost daily communications from Adelaide merchants and private individuals who were in urgent need of glass for glass-houses, tomato-growing, and building purposes, and complaining pf the delay in having orders fulfilled. Finally, merchants and others were obliged to place orders overseas; but when consignments reached Australia, the Government, acting in the interests of the New South Wales company, withheld permission to clear the whole of the stocks from bond. Consequently, owing to the shortage of supplies, many glasshouse frames in South Australia were not covered, and could not be used for the purposes intended. A great deal of evidence was tendered to the board by representatives of both merchants and users, showing that they were unable to obtain supplies. The board has published a statement read by Mr. J. M. Harvey, on behalf of Clarkson Limited, Rundlestreet, Adelaide, one of the largest distributors in that city. This shows that immediately the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited commenced manufacturing, Clarkson Limited placed a small order to test out quality and delivery. The order was given on the 2nd November, 1931, for 112 boxes of sheet glass for November-December delivery, and delivery was made in the following order: 17th June, 1932, 5 cases; 20th June, 21 cases; 30th June, 30 cases; 11th August, 43 cases; 19th September, 10 cases; 8th September, 10 cases; making a total of 119 cases. Mr. Harvey presented to the board the following summary or the transaction : - 20th October. 1931 - The Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited wrote promising delivery of sheet glass, NovemberDecember. 2nd November, 1931 - Clarkson Limited ordered 112 boxes sheet glass, NovemberDecember delivery. 28th November, 1931 - Clarkson Limited wrote intimating stocks exceedingly low, and asking for frank statement of their position. 1st December 11)31 - Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited replied, intimating that shipment would be made on 28th January. 1932. 8th December, 1.931 - Clarkson Limited wrote pointing out that our stock of sheet glass was reduced to danger point, and that we had postponed importing in view of their promise. 16th January, 1932 - Australian Window Class Proprietary Limited wrote stating they were drawing glass on 18th January, 1932, and would send immediately a representative shipment so that we could judge quality.

Several other communications passed between Clarkson Limited and the Australian Window Glass Proprietary Limited, and finally on the 9th June, 1932, Clarkson Limited wrote stating that they had been compelled to send an order overseas. It was not until the 8th September that the firm received the last ten cases to complete the order placed on the 2nd November of the previous year.

I went to the trouble on Friday of telephoning to some of those mentioned in the Tariff Board's report, and asking them whether they had got into touch with the Sydney factory. I spoke to the principal of Messrs. L. G. Abbott, Limited, who stated that he had paid a visit to the factory, and had been surprised to observe the headway made. He was convinced that the factory was now in a position to supply all the requirements of the trade; indeed, to supply all the glass the Australian market could absorb. The quality, he said, was satisfactory both for building and horticultural purposes. He was open and frank with me on the subject of the Tariff Board's recommendation, saying that, in his opinion, the proposed duties were inadequate to meet the situation. I believe with him that it would be possible for the company to carry on under duties of1d. British, and l1/2d. foreign. I believe that, when the item again goes before the Tariff Board, find the members of that body are acquainted with the measures the company has taken to meet requirements, they will make a different recommendation to Parliament. I am pleased that the Minister has consented to refer the item once more to the board.

Mr.WATKINS (Newcastle) [11.13].- I was pleased to hear the honorable member for Adelaide (Mr. Stacey) speak in defence of this industry; it was most refreshing after having had to listen to so many anti- Australian speeches. The most remarkable feature of the Tariff Board's activities is that, in respect of this industry and the pearl shell industry, it has usurped the prerogative of Parliament by recommending certain scales of duties, not on the merits of the industries concerned, but because certain foreign countries buy our products.

Plate glass is not made in this country, and sheet glass is; yet there is a revenue duty of 10s. British and 15s. general per 100 sq. ft. on plate glass, and a duty of only 2s. per 100 sq. ft. on sheet glass. Now we are being asked to agree to reduced duties so that Belgium may supply three-quarters of the Australian market, and the local industry the other quarter. I have always stood for the protection of Australian industry so that employment may be provided for our own people.

Mr.DEIN (Lang) [11.15].- The glass manufacturing industry in Australia has had a checkered career. Undoubtedly a mistake has been made by the Tariff Board in one or other of its recommendations regarding it. According to the 1925 report, the manufacturers were to be given a guarantee that, if the industry were established in Australia, it would receive at least sufficient protection to enable it to carry on. Another report was submitted later reversing the previous recommendation, and practically threatening to crush the industry altogether. Since the Scullin Government, in 1930, gave effect to the recommendations of the Tariff Board's 1925 report the enterprise has expanded enormously. [Quorum formed.] Not only has the number of employees been increased to 240, but the quality of the glass produced is now admittedly good. The output is sufficient to meet local requirements, and the price has been cut by half. The board evidently felt a difficulty about making a recommendation, because in one paragraph it suggests that the rates now operating, namely, 2s. British, and 4s. general, remain in the schedule for twelve months, and that they be terminated or continued after that period according to whether or not it can be shown that they have been effective. The deferred duties of 45 per cent. British, and 75 per cent. general, are higher than those previously recommended by the Tariff Board, namely, 40 per cent. and 60 per cent. The board states that, in order to give the industry effective protection, 100 per cent. British and 175 per cent. general would be necessary, but that it was not prepared to recommend duties so high. However, it went to the other extreme, and recommended duties which were unreasonably low. It should be possible to fix upon some rate between the two which would conform to the requirement of " reasonable " stipulated in the Ottawa agreement. This industry needs a reasonable amount of protection, because of its high labour costs. In Belgium, there are no arbitration courts, and the overhead charges are not nearly so high as they are in Australia, where factory legislation necessitates considerable expenditure in the provision of proper ventilation, lighting and sanitation. The duties recommended by the Tariff Board would result in the destruction of this industry, and enable Glass Distributors Limited to adopt, even more rigorously than in the past, the methods that it has employed to keep traders under its heel, or to drive them out of business. Those who have investigated the practices of this organization will admit that it is relentless, ruthless, and rapacious. I have a good deal of correspondence before me showing how it has kept its clients well under its thumb. As the Government has decided to refer the matter again to the Tariff Board, I shall not give details of the letters before me; but I shall read the following t clause of the agreement, which the clients of Glass Distributors Limited are asked to sign : -

The company, by its directors, from time to time, and it' and when it considers it desirable, may fix the price at which all glass so ordered bv the principal, sha.ll he retailed by the principal to its customers, and the principal shall he bound by the price so fixed.

In cases where firms have sold glass at 3d. under the amount stipulated in the price-list issued by this organization, fines have been inflicted. In other instances, calls on shares have been made to the extent of £300 or £400, with the result that more than one trader has been forced out of business. Such practices should not be permitted. So strongly did I feel on this matter last year that, in August, I wrote to the Attorney-General (Mr. Latham), asking if the federal authorities had any power to deal with this organization. One paragraph of the reply that I received is as follows: -

The position is, it is understood, that the company named has made arrangements with British makers of glass whereby it controls all British glass imported into New South Wales. The situation is no doubt similar to that existing in Queensland under the activities of a company called Glass Distributors (Queensland) Limited. Investigation was made last year as to the position in Queensland, and the matter was referred to the Commonwealth Crown Law authorities for advice as to whether the Commonwealth could take action. The department was advised that it did not appear that any prosecution could be successfully launched against the company under Commonwealth law.

If the Government has not power to deal with such practices the law should he altered to enable it to do so. The question that this committee must decide is whether the local industry shall live and continue to employ Australian workmen, or whether Glass Distributors Limited shall be allowed to continue its nefarious practices at the expense of our workmen.

Prior to the establishment of the industry in New South Wales, the local company approached the Belgian manufacturers for the right to manufacture under their process, and the sum of £80,000 was paid for this privilege. The local company has shown that, with Australian labour, it is able to produce glass of good quality at a reasonable price, and the result has been that the Belgian manufacturers who were paid the.s £80,000 are taking all possible steps in conjunction with Glass Distributors Limited to crush the Australian industry. Because I consider that every member of this Parliament should make it his business to acquaint himself with the nature of the activities of Australian industries, about nine months ago I visited the factory in New South* Wales, and, recently, having read of the improved methods that had been adopted by the local manufacturers, I paid a second visit. I was convinced of the increased efficiency of the industry. .1. saw glass of excellent quality being made, and a huge quantity in store. It proved conclusively to me, at any rate, that the industry is capable of doing all that it claims to be able to do.
